To give them a reason to stay it was important to improve their condition, which included their housing:

In the same way that the unacceptable division of property demands reform, so does the unacceptable state of the farmer's houses, stables and barns. The planning of a comprehensive housing program for the East has already come to its completion. This program also involves the architectural reconstruction of the towns in the East, which should once again become centers of a German will for reconstruction as they were in earlier days, and like the German farms and villages, symbols of German life and German creation. 16

We have some remarkable accounts that attest to Himmler's obsession with this utopian project. One of them dates from early 1940, and was written by Himmler's personal friend Hanns Johst. The latter travelled with Himmler through Poland to inspect the progress of a program of ethnic cleansing, and recorded how, repeatedly during their trip,

the Reichsführer-SS stopped the car, climbed over the striated ditches, walked into the fields ploughed over by grenade shells, took some dirt between his fingers, smelled it thoughtfully with inclined head, crushed the crumbs of the field between his fingers, and then looked over the vast, vast space which was full, full to the horizon, with this good, fertile earth. Thus we stood like ancient farmers and we smiled at each other with twinkling eyes. All of this was now German soil!

And the two men considered how the German settlers would soon change the appearance of the land. Here trees and hedges would be planted. Shrubs would grow, and weasels and hedgehogs, buzzards, and falcons would prevent half of the harvest from perishing because of mice and vermin. All of this was a great work of culture undertaken in awe of nature. And they speculated on how these changes would "create protection from the wind, increase dew, and stimulate the formation of clouds, force rain, and thus push a more economically viable climate further toward the East." And, referring to the great resettlement programs already underway, they predicted that "under professional, rational, and scientific leadership, the Balt, Galician, and Volhynian returnees will do miracles." And Johst recorded how the two men stood in the fields, held conquered soil in their hands, and gazed "over the whole of these indifferently treated surfaces...populat[ing] them with villages surrounded by rustling orchards..." Almost as a kind of afterthought he jotted down that "the Western world cannot understand this pure pleasure derived from task and work, from sweat and calluses. It thinks in terms of business and turnover, where we look forward to action!!" 17

Neither Himmler nor Johst bothered about the millions of gentile and Jewish Poles who were to be deported from their farms, villages, and towns to make space for the ethnic German arrivals. On their trip through Poland Himmler and Johst visited Upper Silesia, in the eastern region where towns like Auschwitz, Blachstadt, and Saybusch, interpreted by Himmler as relics of German medieval colonization, had become centers of ethnic cleansing and large-scale ecological, architectural, and urban reconstruction. In a meeting in the government house of Upper Silesia, located in the town of Kattowitz, Himmler and the military and civilian authorities in the region talked openly about the policies to be enacted:

These lecturers do not speak in commonplaces, which one can noddingly affirm without further thought. They present the hard facts, and they ask concrete questions of Heinrich Himmler in his capacity as chief of the resettlement. He takes the podium and in his final answer gives these gentlemen and their departments clear and forcible directions.

Johst was enthralled:

It is wonderful to experience how here one calmly and dispassionately organizes the migration of whole nations. Hundreds of thousands of people stream into the Reich, and are settled in the East...others are deported...and it all happens while the nation fights the greatest defensive battle for its existence. Everything happens as if it were the most self-evident, the simplest issue in the world!

And he added, "at such moments I almost understand the hatred of the Western world for everything German. Nothing was ever so hateful as superiority, as natural superiority, by virtue of the belief in an idea, by virtue of achievements, and by virtue of results." 18

Johst was not the only one who would be astonished at the frankness with which Himmler discussed in public the nature and impact of his policies. In his notorious speech given to the SS leadership on 4 October 1943, Himmler discussed the Holocaust openly, congratulating himself and his comrades for the fact that they had "carried out this heaviest of our tasks in a spirit of love for our people. And our inward being, our soul, our character has not suffered injury from it." 19 A year earlier he had discussed with equal frankness the problem of labor in the German East. Originally Himmler had intended to rely on the Reich Labor Service for the labor to plant new forests, drain the marshes, build the roads, prepare the settlements, and so on. But by 1942 the whole of the Reich Labor Service had been mobilized for the war and ceased to be at Himmler's disposal. Himmler could not wait until the Reich Labor Service could furnish manpower for peacetime projects. Noting that the SS had been charged with providing a stable foundation for a German future in the East, "a foundation that allows individuals who come fifty, eighty, one hundred, or two hundred years after us to cave in or to lose their heads without endangering the future of the German Imperium," Himmler announced the formation of an enormous army of slaves:

If we do not create the bricks here, if we do not fill our camps with slaves--in this room I state these things precisely and clearly--with workslaves who will build our cities, our villages, and our farms, irrespective of losses, then, after a long war, we will not have the money to create such settlements that allow a truly Germanic people to live with dignity and take root within one generation." 20

Himmler's use of the word "bricks" had both a metaphorical and literal sense. The German concentration camps, which Himmler controlled as Reichsführer-SS, had acquired in the late 1930s a key role in the German production of building materials. Originally intended as an instrument of terror to stabilize the National Socialist regime, at first the camps had not been used to furnish labor for productive work, as this would have competed with German business and hindered the reduction of high unemployment. By 1937, however, the camps were becoming superfluous as political tools, for the regime was now firmly established and enjoyed general approval. The number of inmates had dropped from 30,000 in early 1934 to 10,000, and a German future without concentration camps had become conceivable. Yet Himmler did not want to close them. First, they provided him a political power base; more important, he very clearly saw the camps' economic potential in a situation of labor shortage. Already in 1936-37 Himmler began to consider the productive potential of possible concentration camp sites. Dachau was to remain where it was, but the new camps at Buchenwald and Sachsenhausen were established in places that seemed optimal. Both were to be involved in the production of bricks to service the local programs of urban reconstruction. With an eye to providing the city of Weimar with brick, the SS decided to locate Buchenwald on the wooded Ettersberg, five miles from the former capital, a site chosen because it was adjacent to large loam and clay deposits. Sachsenhausen was to serve Speer's building program in Berlin; located twenty-five miles north of the city along the Hohenzollern canal in the town of Oranienburg, it offered good possibilities for bulk transport to the capital. Having decided on the location of these two camps, in early 1938 Himmler founded the Deutsche Erd und Steinwerke (DESt, or German Earth and Stone Works) to set up and run the brickworks at Buchenwald, Sachsenhausen, and possibly other places, as well as to open and exploit granite quarries. The first brickyard to be opened was the one near Buchenwald, planned to have a capacity of 7 million bricks per year. With a subsidy of RM 9.5 million given by Speer, DESt also began construction of a brickyard in Oranienburg, intended to be the largest brickyard in the world with an annual production of 150 million bricks, ten times as many as the largest existing brickyards could yield. The same year DESt bought a defunct brickyard near Hamburg and began to plan a 40-million-brick-a-year production facility to supply the reconstruction of Hamburg. A new concentration camp, Neuengamme, was built adjacent to the factory.

To supply Speer with granite, DESt began to operate granite quarries in 1938. The first two to be acquired were a quarry near Flossenbürg, close to the Czech border in the Upper Palatinate, and a famous granite quarry adjacent to the Upper Austrian town of Mauthausen, near Linz. Before 1914 the quarries of Mauthausen had supplied most of the granite used in Vienna, Budapest, and the smaller cities of the former Austrian-Hungarian empire. 21 The quality of the stone and the town's location along a major transport corridor had contributed to its fame. With the dissolution of the empire, however, Mauthausen had fallen on hard times. Demand for granite had decreased, even as the use of concrete increased. For the town of Mauthausen the Anschluss of 1938 was a welcome event; in Hitler's Germany, granite was again the premier building material for public buildings. A few days after the Anschluss, Himmler and his aide Oswald Pohl, who controlled the administration of the SS and its companies, toured the Mauthausen area with an eye to establishing a DESt branch to exploit its riches. After some negotiation, the city leased two quarries to DESt; adjacent to each, the SS began to build a camp. The same pattern was applied in Flossenbürg, and to DESt operations in Silesia and the Alsace. Quarries were identified and assessed in relation to transport and markets, then leased or purchased, and finally complemented by new camps to provide labor: in Silesia the quarries, which Speer had designated as the main suppliers of Berlin, were to be serviced by Gross-Rosen and in the Alsace, by Natzweiler. In some cases the pattern was reversed. The concentration camp in Auschwitz, for example, was established adjacent to the formerly Polish town because of demographic and political reasons. But within a few months of its establishment, DESt acquired a gravel and sand production facility close to the camp.

More important than the production of gravel was Auschwitz's function as a labor reserve to facilitate German reconstruction of the eastern part of Upper Silesia. For various eco-nomic and geopolitical reasons, Auschwitz had attracted the attention of the men charged by Himmler with the long-range planning of the German East. As early as July 1940 Himmler had been convinced by Professor Doktor Konrad Meyer that a speedy Germanization of the area around Auschwitz was of the highest priority. 22 Himmler's Chief of Staff, Ulrich Greifelt, concurred. "It is very urgent at this point to create a purely ethnic German corner," he wrote, also suggesting several communities as potential places of settlement by ethnic Germans, among them the town of Auschwitz and the nearby village of Birkenau (fig. 3). 23 On Thursday, 10 October 1940 a meeting held in Kattowitz and attended by the SS and Upper Silesia's civil servants decided that part of the new province was going to be used for massive settlement by ethnic Germans. A map created for this meeting designated the area around Auschwitz as Siedlungszone 1a (Zone of Settlement 1a) (fig. 4). 24 This designation implied that the given area offered few impediments to the envisioned physical and social trans-formation. A master plan for the future of the region was to be completed by the spring of 1941. 25

Planning started quickly indeed. The Germans set to work on both regional and municipal designs. In December 1940 the architect Dr. Hans Stosberg accepted the task of creating a master plan for the reconstruction and enlargement of Auschwitz. After two months of work he produced a preliminary design (fig. 5), accompanied by an explanatory document that is printed as an appendix to this essay. 26 It noted that Auschwitz was located at the center of three major industrial areas, and that it offered good building ground and a bountiful supply of water. This was important because of the Upper Silesian coal mines located on the watershed between the Oder and the Vistula; their coal, being of relatively low grade, was intended to serve as raw material for chemical industries, but the unavailability of water effectively prevented the location of such plants adjacent to the mines. Auschwitz, because of the confluence of three rivers, was the closest site with the requisite water supply. Stosberg's draft assumes a city of first 35,500, and later 47,000 inhabitants. The largest single employer would be the chemical industry, an IG Farben plant, to make artificial rubber from coal, a complex that would employ 3,000 people who were to live in their own quarter. Eventually, both the plant and a small part of the IG Farben neighborhood were built. The draft continues with the railways, which would employ 1,500 people. These workers and their [Begin Page 93] families would live in a quarter close to the station. The document also mentions "SS and ancillary businesses (but not the barracks and the concentration camp inmates)." This would involve 1,500 workplaces.

Stosberg's design was faced with a number of vexing limitations. Space was tight. It was clear that the industry was to go to the town's east. To the south there was a large floodplain unsuitable for anything but recreational use; to the north the same condition applied; and to the west the town was surrounded on three sides by the concentration camp's Interes-sengebiet (Zone of Interests), which was forbidden territory. In his initial report of December 1940, Stosberg had thought it possible to harmonize the needs of the concentration camp for security with the needs of the town for breathing space. But as he continued to design and the camp continued to expand, relations between Stosberg and the SS soured. Stosberg and SS architect Hartjenstein developed mutually exclusive plans for the quarter located between the railway lines with the station, the Stammlager in Zasole, and the river Sola (fig. 6). 27 Stosberg's design for the civic peninsula that carved its way from the river bank into the camp's Zone of Interests was meant to provide citizens with a dignified if not festive access to the trains by means of a great boulevard that was to be the spine of New Town West, a densely built-up neighborhood for 7,500 people. Hartjenstein's proposal for the SS settle-ment engulfed some fifty percent of Stosberg's neighborhood, reducing it to what Stosberg termed a "torso." Furthermore, the vernacular character of the SS Garden City with its cozy one-family homesteads set in large gardens contradicted the strongly urban character of Stosberg's plan, a note the latter considered appropriate for the central urban axis connecting the city's major elements: the station to the medieval Ring and, beyond that, the new plaza (Parteiforum) that was to embody Auschwitz's dignity as capital of a new county (fig. 7), the eastern neighborhood, and the immense IG Farben plant that was to provide the economic justification for all these improvements.

There were really two solutions to the problem: either the SS settlement had to conform to the urban density of Stosberg's plan, providing an appropriate southern flank to the avenue mentioned above, or the SS had to move the Garden City to another site within their Zone of Interests, allowing for a new border between the city and the camp, one closer to the Stammlager. Stosberg was supported by the provincial bureaucracy. But the camp also had strong supporters, not the least of whom was Himmler. The two parties argued for almost a year, pushing the border between the city and the camp up and down between the proposed avenue and the perimeter of the camp. Ultimately the issue was settled in favor of the city; in a large meeting held in Auschwitz on Wednesday, 23 September, the chief of the SS-Wirtschafts Verwaltungshauptamt (WVHA, or SS Economic and Administrative Department), SS-Obergruppenführer (General) Oswald Pohl, withdrew Hartjenstein's proposal and an-nounced that he had ordered the architect to prepare a master plan that moved the settlement to the south side of the Stammlager, firmly within the camp's Zone of Interests. 28 None of these difficulties was anticipated in Stosberg's 1941 report. There he still assumed that the camp's development would not obstruct the "organic" development of the town. In view of the later use of Auschwitz-Birkenau as an extermination plant, it is ironic that Stosberg identified that area (between the station and the Vistula) as a good site to establish "SS industrial installations."

Stosberg continued to work on his plan, of which important relics remain. One is a double-folded New Year's greeting card that he sent in December 1941. On the front he wished his benefactors and friends "health, happiness, and a good outcome for every new beginning." The inside spread showed his proposal for the rehabilitation of Auschwitz's market (fig. 8), while the back contained a four-sentence meditation placing Auschwitz firmly within the National Socialist Myth of the German East:

In the year 1241 Silesian knights, acting as saviors of the Reich, warded off the Mongolian assault at Wahlstatt. In that same century Auschwitz was founded as a German town. After six hundred years the Führer Adolf Hitler is turning the Bolshevik menace away from Europe. This year, 1941, the construction of a new German city and the reconstruction of the old Silesian market have been planned and initiated. 29

As we will see below, the suggested relation between Hitler's attack on the Soviet Union and the reconstruction of Auschwitz did not exist only in history. It also applied to space.

The realization of Stosberg's proposal depended on the availability of labor. Himmler was to oblige him. On 1 March 1941, on his way to a gathering of Bukowinian Germans who were waiting in camps in and around Breslau for their final resettlement in the region just south of Auschwitz, Himmler visited Auschwitz and ordered the construction of a large prisoner-of-war camp in Birkenau. A few weeks earlier he had been informed of Hitler's decision to attack the Soviet Union in the spring, and Himmler had immediately recognized that the expected mass of Soviet prisoners of war would provide him with the labor force he needed to continue the reconstruction of the German East. As the area around Auschwitz had been assigned top priority in this project, it made sense for the region to receive the bulk of prisoners of war who would be transferred into SS custody by the Army. According to the commandant of the concentration camp, Rudolf Höss, the various provincial officials present at Himmler's visit were not very happy at the prospect of 100,000 Soviet prisoners two [Begin Page 96] kilometers from Auschwitz, and raised their objections with the Reichsführer-SS. "Himmler just smiled," Höss recalled in 1946, "and disposed of their objections saying, 'Gentlemen, this project will be completed; my reasons are more important than your objections!'" 30 Even purely technical objections were not taken seriously. The wetlands of Birkenau were of crucial significance for the province's future. Most of Upper Silesia's population lived in a densely settled industrial belt occupying a plateau that formed, as we saw before, a watershed between the rivers Oder and Vistula; as a result the region lacked water, a deficiency that potentially limited future develop-ment. To redress this, the province had designated the lowland between the Vistula and the Sola as a major water reservoir for the industrial heart of Upper Silesia. 31 Provincial bureaucrats now argued that the sewage of 100,000 people was going to make it impossible to maintain the water quality, but Himmler impatiently dismissed their concerns: water management was merely a matter of technology to be solved by the experts (Höss, 285).

On Sunday, 22 June 1941 the German army surprised the Soviet Union in an early morning attack. Goebbels instructed the media to report the war in the East as the unmasking of "the greatest Jewish swindle of all times." The press got instructions to present the situation in the Soviet Union through

an impressive juxtaposition of inhuman conditions in the Soviet Union on the one hand and the social progress, the high cultural standard, and the healthy Lebensfreude of the working man in National Socialist Germany on the other. A good choice of pictures, contrasting the bestialized bolshevik types with the free and open gaze of the German worker, filthy Soviet hutments with German workers' settlements, muddy tracks with the German Reich highways, etc., will be of particular importance in this connexion. 32

From this it was only a small step to a rhetoric pitting the European Mensch against the Soviet Untermensch, which had come to mean a Russian in the clutches of Judeo-bolshevism.

The simple polarization of human being versus subhuman was graphically depicted in Der Untermensch, an SS publication released simultaneously in fifteen European languages to arouse enthusiasm across the continent for the German crusade in the East. An organ for Himmler's view of history, Der Untermensch emphasized the centuries-old conflict between the European Mensch and the predecessors of the Soviet Untermensch, the Hun and Mongol horsemen, whom the National Socialists conflated and confused. In this section, a two-page spread depicted the Hun/Mongol nemesis of the past and the Soviet enemy of the present. Mounted Huns trampling Germanic women and children were shown on the left, while on the right were portraits of six Soviet prisoners of war. "The challenge of the Untermensch began with the bloody rides of [the Hun] Attila and [the Mongol] Genghis Khan," explained the text on the left. "On ugly little horses, almost grown together with the skin of their animals, the Hun hordes dashed against Europe. Their split eyes glowed with lust to kill and behind them they left only wilderness, murder, fire, and destruction." And, turning to the picture of the prisoners of war, the caption continued on the right-hand page, "now they are here again, the Huns, caricatures of human faces, nightmares that have become reality, a fist blow into the face of all that is good." 33

Convinced that the war against the Soviet Union was a crusade to protect European civili-zation against Asian barbarism, the leadership of the German army had decided on 8 September 1941 that rules of war established by custom and formulated in international law did not apply to the war in the East. This decision reflected a widely felt German sentiment. More than a month before the German attack on the Soviet Union, Colonel-General Höpner, commander of Panzer Group Four, had written:

The war against the Soviet Union is an essential component of the German people's struggle for existence. It is the old struggle of the Germans against the Slavs, the defense of European culture against the Muscovite-Asiatic fold, the warding-off of Jewish Bolshevism ...Both the planning and the execution of every battle must be dictated by an iron will to bring about a merciless, total annihilation of the enemy. 34

In early October another commander reminded his soldiers that their task was "the complete destruction" of the Soviet army and "the eradication of the Asiatic influence on the European cultural sphere." German troops had special tasks

which go beyond the conventional unilateral soldierly tradition. In the East the [German] soldier is not only a fighter according to the rules of war, but also a carrier of an inexorable racial conception and the avenger of all the bestialities which have been committed against the Germans and related races. 35

And in November another commander explained to his troops:

Here in the East spiritually unbridgeable conceptions are fighting each other: a German sense of honor and race, and a soldierly tradition of many centuries, against an Asiatic mode of thinking and primitive instincts, whipped up by a small number of mostly Jewish intellectuals...We clearly recognize our mission to save European culture from the advancing Asiatic barbarism...This battle can only end with the destruction of one or the other; compromise is out of the question. 36

The new attitude also affected the treatment of Soviet prisoners of war. In the notorious "Guidelines for the Treatment of Political Commissars," better known as the "Commissar Order," which was issued on 6 June 1941, the German army was forbidden to grant prisoner-of-war status to captured Soviet political commissars. Instead these "bearers of the Judeo-Bolshevik world view" were to be shot after identification. The army's acceptance of the Commissar Order opened the road for more violations of international law. On 28 June 1941, the general in charge of the Prisoner of War Department of the German Army High Command concluded a draft agreement with the SS that allowed SS Einsatzkommandos (Special Units) to enter prisoner-of-war camps to select and execute already imprisoned commissars, communist functionaries of all ranks, agitators and fanatical communists, and "all Jews." 37 This agreement came into force on 17 July. The army justified it by noting that "the special situation of the Eastern campaign...demands special measures." Military consi-derations were now going to give way to the "political objective," which was to "protect the German nation from Bolshevik inciters." 38

Less dramatic, but ultimately more deadly, was the German unwillingness to provide the remaining prisoners with sufficient accommodation. Three major international conventions, the First Hague Convention , the Second Hague Convention , and the Geneva Convention had established minimal standards of prisoner maintenance. Yet because the Soviet Union had not been a signatory to the last convention, which had merely clarified certain points of the earlier ones that were already ruling as law on the basis of custom, the German high command was led to the criminal assumption that none of the conventions applied. I will discuss some of their provisions later in more detail. Suffice it note that already in the early summer of 1941 catastrophic conditions began to occur in the camps holding Soviet prisoners of war. "Camps" is in fact a euphemism: a camp consisted of fields surrounded by barbed-wire fences. The inmates were to build themselves shelters, but no materials were provided. One of them, camp Lamsdorf in Silesia, reportedly held some 200,000 prisoners:

The camp was simply a square area of land where most of the Russians huddled together in huts made from the earth which they had built themselves. Food distribution to the camp was irregular and totally inadequate. The prisoners cooked for themselves in fire pits in the ground (Höss, 132).

Unwilling and unable to deal with the problem, the army negotiated a transfer of Soviet pri-soners with Himmler. 39 As we have seen, on Saturday, 1 March 1941 Himmler had desig-nated Birkenau as the site for a large camp. Yet for months nothing had been done toward its construction, and no funds had been allocated. When the Soviet prisoners arrived in early October in Birkenau, there was no camp available. Yet the Germans were happy to supply the designs. In fact, they had created a new architectural office headed by Karl Bischoff (fig. 9). Bischoff had begun work in early October 1941, and a first master plan was drawn by his assistant, the thirty-three-year-old Bauhaus graduate Fritz Ertl, on 7 October (fig. 10). The plan proposed a two-part camp for a total of 97,000 inmates. The smaller part, Bauabschnitt I (Building Sector I, abbreviated as BA I), which could hold a little under 17,000 inmates, was a quarantine camp, a reasonable provision given the bad physical condition of the arriving prisoners; the larger part, Bauabschnitt II (Building Sector II, abbreviated as BA II), designed to hold a little over 80,000 inmates, was the main camp. They were separated by a "neutral zone" (fig. 11). In a meeting held in mid-October the plan was modified, creating a second version that became the basis for a fourteen-page document that explains the design in detail. 40 The most important change was an increase in the camp's capacity from 97,000 to 125,000 inmates. One drawing, which shows a section of the standard hut to be built, leaves no doubt that the increase was achieved by cramming more inmates into the same space. The original drawing, signed by Bischoff on 8 October, listed a capacity of 550 men (fig. 12). A week later Bischoff had crossed out the "550" and replaced it with "744". 41 Nothing else had changed. Perhaps Bischoff's decision was inspired by the arrival of the first prisoners of war. "They arrived in Auschwitz after long weeks of marching with very little food supplied to them on route. During the breaks in their march they were simply led into nearby fields and told to 'graze' like cattle on everything that was edible." Having arrived, "they walked around aimlessly in a daze, or they crawled anywhere into a protected area to swallow something edible that they found. They tried to force it down their throats, or they simply, quietly, found a place to die" (Höss, 133). Fear of anarchy also led to another modification: the main camp (BA II) was now to be subdivided into twelve smaller, self-sufficient "camps"--an arrangement that was to persist throughout all subsequent modifications (BA IIa, b, c, d, e and f). Yet another modification was the inclusion of a rail spur to connect the camp directly to the railway junction a mile to the east. In the future prisoners were to arrive by train (fig. 13).

Working in a hurry, Bischoff had been drawing plans without informing Berlin and with no sense of available funding. On 25 October, SS headquarters telegraphed Bischoff to remind him that a budget could not be approved unless he submitted the plans according to the usual procedures. 42 A package was hastily created. The total budget was to be RM 8.9 million, which compares in 1993 to $36 million. In an accompanying letter Bischoff wrote that BA I was already under construction and would be finished in fourteen days. It was not the last time that Bischoff turned out to be far too optimistic about the amount of con-struction that could be achieved in Auschwitz. The Soviet prisoners, as Höss observed, were "perfectly willing to work, but unable to accomplish anything because of their weakened condition...The entire body organism was finished and could no longer function" (Höss, 132f.). None of this affected calculations back in Berlin: the SS head office reduced the total cost from RM 8.9 million to RM 7.7 million. The standard rate for labor costs did not apply because the prisoners were to build the camp themselves, and for free.

Closer study of the actual designs reveals how the Nazi identification of the Soviet soldier as an Untermensch was translated into architectural terms. The prisoners were to be housed in 174 barracks. Each barrack was to measure 116 ft. by 36 ft., that is, 4,176 sq. ft. Total volume was 13,257 cu. ft. The barrack was subdivided into 62 bays, each of 43 sq. ft., and each bay had three "roosts" (fig. 14). Originally a roost was supposed to hold three prisoners, but, as we have seen, in mid-October the capacity had been increased to four. To sleep, sit, and keep his belongings, each prisoner was now provided with "private" space that amounted to 11 sq. ft., the dimensions of a large coffin, or an average volume of 53 cu. ft., the size of a shallow grave. The cost per barrack was to be RM 12,400, that is, RM 16.67 per inmate.

Inmates were being deprived of the minimum space needed to exist. Tadeusz Borowski, who was interned in Auschwitz in 1943 as prisoner number 119,198, described the condi-tions in the camp as more horrendous than medieval fantasies about hell:

If the barrack walls were suddenly to fall away, many thousands of people, packed together, squeezed tightly in their bunks, would remain suspended in mid-air. Such a sight would be more gruesome than medieval paintings of the Last Judgment. For one of the ugliest sights to a man is that of another man sleeping on his tiny portion of the bunk, of the space which he must occupy, because he has a body--a body that has been exploited to the utmost: with a number tattooed on it to save on dog tags, with just enough sleep at night to work during the day, and just enough time to eat. And just enough food so it will not die wastefully. As for actual living there is only one place for it--a piece of bunk. The rest belongs to the camp, the Fatherland. 43

Borowski's comparison with medieval visions of hell was apt. Yet if there is a certain justification to the sufferings of medieval sinners who have been judged by God, nothing can justify the treatment of inmates at Birkenau, arbitrarily selected by an SS doctor. In the medieval paintings and reliefs, guilt and retribution are still related as cause and effect; in Birkenau it is the other way around. In a Kafkaesque inversion of crime and punishment, the camps first penalized people and then made them guilty. Anyone forced to live in the barracks could only become an object lesson for a photo-essay exploring the life and appearance of the Untermensch.

The extraordinarily small space allocated to each inmate and the high mortality rate within the huts meant that inmates would often die during the night, and that those who were still alive had no way to remove the corpses. Primo Levi, who experienced this in January 1945, reflected on the implications of this forced intimacy between the living and the dead:

It is man who kills, man who creates or suffers injustice; it is no longer man who, having lost all restraint, shares his bed with a corpse. Whoever waits for his neighbour to die in order to take his piece of bread is, albeit guiltless, further from the model of thinking man than the most primitive pygmy or the most vicious sadist.
Part of our existence lies in the feelings of those near to us. This is why the experience of someone who has lived for days during which man was merely a thing in the eyes of man is non-human. 44 [Begin Page 103]

Confronted with such a world we, outsiders, can only react like the Soviet soldiers who liber-ated the camp the next day. Levi described how they stood at the barbed wire, looking at the emaciated prisoners and the corpses. "They did not greet us, nor did they smile; they seemed oppressed not only by compassion but by a confused restraint, which sealed their lips and bound their eyes to the funereal scene." It was not that they were horrified; these were veter-ans who had fought westward from Stalingrad to Auschwitz. The hardened soldiers were not horrified, but ashamed--ashamed of being human:

It was that shame we knew so well, the shame that drowned us after the selections, and every time we had to watch, or submit to, some outrage: the shame the Germans did not know, that the just man experiences at another man's crime; the feeling of guilt that such a crime should exist, that it should have been introduced irrevocably into the world of things that exist. 45

The design, which postulated a living space so tiny that it was fit for a coffin and not a human being, showed a blatant disregard for international law protecting prisoners of war. According to article 7 of the 1899 Hague Convention, "prisoners of war shall be treated as regards food, quarters, and clothing, on the same footing as the troops of the government which has captured them." 46 This principle was reaffirmed in a second convention in 1907. The German General Staff acknowledged its validity. Their sole clarification of article 7 was that the prisoners were to be treated like German soldiers, "not worse, but also not better." 47 The 1929 Geneva Convention sought to define the standard soldier with whom a prisoner should be compared. Article 10 of the 1929 convention established two criteria. First, prisoners were to "be lodged in buildings or in barracks affording all possible guarantees of hygiene and healthfulness. The quarters must be fully protected from dampness, sufficiently heated and lighted. All precautions must be taken against danger of fire." This statement was open to interpretation. It assumed a compromise between generally accepted standards of comfort and healthiness and limitations on the means of the detaining power to meet them. Second, a more objective standard was given: "with regard to dormitories--the total surface, minimum cubic amount of air, arrangement and material of bedding--the conditions shall be the same as for the troops at base camps of the detaining power." 48 The designation "base camps" indicated that the norm was not the accommodation of soldiers in the trenches, but of those at rest or in training in the rear. As prisoner-of-war camps were supposed to be in the rear, in practice this meant that the accommodations of the prisoners and their guards were to be comparable. That this was not the case at Birkenau is demonstrated by a photo illustrating the guards' quarters (fig. 15). For a bedroom of nine guards official guidelines stipulated 3,600 cu. ft., or 400 cu. ft. per person. That is, eight times as much space allocated for sleeping accommodations alone, to which one might add dining halls, recreation rooms, and so on. 49

This should suffice. Yet a perverse curiosity makes us compare the accommodations at the prisoner-of-war camp at Birkenau with the official SS standards for concentration-camp barracks. On the same day that Bischoff had begun work in Birkenau, his immediate superior, Dr. Hans Kammler, issued a standard plan for the accommodation of concentration-camp inmates (fig. 16). 50 Comparison of the two plans reveals how the Germans treated the Soviet Untermensch in comparison with European inmates. To allow for a fair comparison we must note that the concentration camp barrack includes a washroom and toilets. When those are taken out of consideration there remains a space of 6,515 sq. ft. for 200 prisoners. At a height of 9 ft. this yields 58,650 cu. ft., or 293 cu. ft. per inmate. That is almost sixfold the space allocated to the Soviet Untermensch. To prevent any misconception: if we compare the 293 cu. ft. allocated to a hypothetical European inmate with the 400 cu. ft. allocated to a guard (see previous paragraph) we must bear in mind that the latter number refers only to the guard's sleeping accommodation, while the 293 cu. ft. is the total living space of the inmate. To continue the comparison: the huts in Birkenau provided 181 sq. ft. of window surface for 744 prisoners, or 0.25 sq. ft. per inmate, while the standard concentration-camp barrack provided eighteen times as much light. The melancholy comparison can be applied to every aspect of the design. In Birkenau the toilets and washrooms were housed in sixteen wash barracks and eighteen latrines; that is, one wash barrack per 7,800 inmates, and one latrine hut per 7,000 inmates. Each hut had a surface of 1,745 sq. ft.; that is, a little more than 0.2 sq. ft. per inmate. The standard concentration-camp hut provides 4.9 sq. ft. of wash space per inmate, almost twenty times as much. Toilet space in the standard camp was less generous at only 2.5 sq. ft. per inmate--but still more than twelve times as much as was allocated to the Soviet Untermensch.

The design of the wash barracks and privies is paradoxically "symbolic" of the fundamentally asymbolic situation of Birkenau. [Begin Page 106] Article 13 of the Geneva Convention required belligerents "to take all sanitary measures necessary to assure the cleanliness and healthfulness of camps and prevent epidemics." Prisoners were to "have at their disposal, day and night, installations conforming to sanitary rules and constantly maintained in a state of cleanliness." They were also to "be furnished a sufficient quantity of water for the care of their own bodily cleanliness." 51 This concern for the prisoners' cleanliness was inspired by the fear of lice, the most common host of the typhus virus. Lack of water, lack of soap, and insufficient change of clothing allow lice to gain a foothold on the human body, and so expose the prisoner population to a typhus epidemic. Yet there is also another reason. It has to do with the fundamentally symbolic nature of the consciousness of the self that makes us unable to live amidst our own excrement. Julia Kristeva has labelled excrement the confusing "abject" that is neither subject (me) nor object (that), "but not nothing either. A 'Something' that I do not recognize as a thing. A weight of meaninglessness, about which there is nothing insignificant, and which crushes me." 52 Excrement, so she believes, links us directly to the child's separation from the mother, and with that to the origin of a person's sense of identity. Describing defilement as the oldest and most universal symbol of evil, Paul Ricoeur has come to the same conclusion. Confronted with the excremental states of dirt, decay, and rot, we feel "a threat which, beyond the threat of suffering and death, aims at a diminution of existence, a loss of the personal core of one's being." 53 In a masterly essay on life in the death camps, the late Terrence Des Pres described what he termed as the camp's "excremental assault" on the inmates. The camp's filth, he argued, was the result of a deliberate policy to destroy the last vestiges of the prisoner's sense of self-worth. It was not enough to kill the prisoners; one had to kill them as totally broken people. Only when the inmates were completely crushed would the SS "reach the orgasmic peak of their potential domination...Spiritual destruction became an end in itself, quite apart from the requirements of mass murder." 54 Des Pres is incorrect in his insistence that defilement was the result of the SS's desire to exercise total power. The root cause was a fundamental inadequacy of design, a lack of willingness on the part of bureaucrats far away from the camp to allocate more than a minimum of material and financial resources for the camp's construction, and an assumption about the camp's use that proved badly mistaken. Yet intended or not, the result was the same: with the latrines submerged in excrement, with very little water to be had at very few points, and with mud everywhere, what remained was an inmate population without any means to preserve the outward signs of human dignity. As Des Pres asked, "how much self-esteem can one maintain, how readily can one respond to the needs of another, if both stink, if both are caked with mud and feces?" (Des Pres, 60). This excremental assault led to the same collapse of symbol and reality we noted with regard to the 53 cu. ft. allocated to each prisoner. In the extreme conditions of the camp, Des Pres reflected, the division between "concrete existence" and "symbolic modes of being" disappeared. "Body and spirit become the ground of each other, each bearing the other's need, the other's sorrow, and each responds directly to the other's total condition" (Des Pres, 65). The result was a situation in which "meaning no longer exists above and beyond the world; it reenters concrete experience, becomes immanent and invests each act and each moment with urgent depth" (Des Pres, 69).

This, then, brings us back to the designs. Were they even competent, given the situation? First, there is the spatial arrangement: the "privy" meant to serve 7,000 inmates is a shed with a single concrete open sewer, 118 ft. long by 3 ft. wide, without seats and with one long beam as a back support (fig. 17). The design was adapted from a model latrine for large units in winter quarters, and was first published in a leaflet on wartime emergency construction (fig. 18). 55 Like the model latrine, the camp latrine pit could be accessed from walkways at both sides. Neither in Auschwitz, nor in the model on which it was based were the walkways connected; but in Auschwitz this proved catastrophic, for each of the walkways was 118 ft. long. Both in the built version and the model, access to the walkways was provided by doors at each of the building's short sides. Imagine 7,000 inmates at sunrise, suffering from diarrhea or dysentery, and trying to enter, find an unoccupied place, defecate, manage not to fall into the sewer, and get out in the ten minutes or so allocated by the camp's regulations to such necessities. Assuming that 150 inmates could find a place at one time, and also assuming that all 7,000 inmates were to move their bowels with the requisite precision, it would require forty-six successive "seatings," with all the traffic jams involved. To be sure, the design might have provided a series of doors on the long sides, like the old English commuter trains used to have, and so accelerated matters significantly; but the basic problem would have remained. One sewer, supplied with an anemic supply of water and a drop of only 1.6 percent could never flush the discharge of 7,000 people in such a short time. The result was a secretory catastrophe. Added to that were omissions in the Auschwitz version that made the whole experience considerably more unpleasant. First, there were no seats. Second, the system of support was based on the minimal design of the field latrine, only to be used at the front. Third, the "shame-walls" were removed, which might have provided at least some physical privacy for those who had to defecate next to each other. Finally, the separate aeration for the pit was omitted (it had become superfluous since the pits at Auschwitz were open), which meant an insufferable stench. Gisella Perl, who was forced to use these latrines after BA I had become the women's camp of Birkenau, gives us a succinct description of the situation delineated in Drawing 795 :

There was one latrine for thirty to thirty-two thousand women and we were permitted to use it only at certain hours of the day. We stood in line to get into this tiny building, knee-deep in human excrement. As we all suffered from dysentery, we could rarely wait until our turn came, and soiled our ragged clothes, which never came off our bodies, thus adding to the horror of our existence by the terrible smell which surrounded us like a cloud.

Added to this was the indignity of the arrangement itself: "The latrine consisted of a deep ditch with planks thrown across it at certain intervals. We squatted on these planks like birds perched on a telegraph wire, so close together that we could not help soiling one another." 56

No explanation can justify or qualify the horror of these provisions. We have seen how decisions about the design were framed by a general ideology that assigned the Soviet prisoner of war the lowly status of Untermensch. But there was also another reason why Ertl and Bischoff thought that they could get away with less than the absolute minimum, a reason explained in one document discussing the intended capacity of the waste-water treatment plant at Birkenau. Originally the camp had been conceived as a base for crews of slave workers who were to be employed in amelioration and construction activities in the surrounding area. As it was to be largely empty during the day, the architects reasoned that even when the camp was filled to capacity, it would be possible to run it with only 66 percent of the minimum sanitary facilities, for prisoners could be serviced by locally dug field latrines at their place of work. 57 The reasoning was mistaken, for it entirely neglected the question of peak use in the early morning and evening, when all the prisoners had to use the facilities simultaneously.

The mistake made the lives of the inmates insufferable. Remarkably, it also created huge problems for the SS. As we have seen, as early as 1 March 1941 provincial officials had noted that the camp's sewage was going to create problems. Himmler had dismissed their concerns then, and he dismissed them again later. Bischoff, characterized by an SS psychologist as a man who was servile towards his superiors, troublesome to his colleagues, and tyrannical to his subordinates, was not going to make trouble about it. 58 Facing serious shortages in material and manpower, the architect callously reasoned that the camp was temporary and that the inmates were going to be working outside during the day: why not dump the camp's sewage directly into the Vistula? In the first brief for the camp, he had projected three sewers to take the waste water from the camp to an open channel directly connected to the Vistula. No screens, sedimentation basins, or other cleansing units were planned. 59 The total budget was RM 250,000, that is, 2.8 percent of a budget of almost RM 9 million. 60

But even this minimal arrangement was not realized. Bischoff blamed a lack of prisoners to dig the trenches. 61 The inmates were not Bischoff's only headache. The local and provincial planners created trouble from the moment that they received Bischoff's proposals. In early February 1942 the provincial chief of construction, [Begin Page 110] Wittmer, predicted that sewage would leak from the open channels into the surrounding area and argued that a flood, which was a distinct possibility in the lowland around Birkenau, would lead to severe pollution. 62 Provincial planner Ziegler concluded that enough was enough, and that it was time to remind Himmler of his responsibilities. In a letter of 18 February 1942 he reminded the Reichsführer-SS that "when I gave my permission some time ago to create a concentration camp I made it clear that a camp of this enormous size, located in such an extraordinarily well situated place for industry (close to coal, at a major road and railway junction, and at the confluence of three rivers), will be expected to accept many conditions in the interest of other parties or for the common good." He noted that Höss had always understood this, and that therefore there had been no problems until then. 63

Ziegler's letter alarmed the SS headquarters; despite appearances, the SS was not omni-potent, and while they certainly had total control over what happened within their camps once they were built, they also had to adhere to normal planning procedures and, if necessary, inspections, while the camps were under construction. Ziegler had the power to stop the expansion of Auschwitz. Hence the SS main office instructed Bischoff to draw up a new plan for the camp's waste-water management which would satisfy the province. Within a week it was completed. For a total expenditure of RM 424,000 Auschwitz-Birkenau would receive a seven-branch sewer that was to have a total length of 1 mile (RM 52,000), three sedimentation basins (RM 205,500), a separate draining system of pipes which connected to a collection pipe for a total length of 9 miles (RM 117,000) and, finally, a 0.7 mile-long open channel to discharge the effluent into the Vistula (RM 49,500). 64

But paper is patient, and little was done. The spring came, and the summer, and the camp continued to expand, and more and more sewage flowed untreated into the Vistula, and relations between the town, the province, and the camp steadily worsened. Finally, on 23 September, the parties came together to settle their differences. It was the same meeting in which the SS yielded on the issue of Hartjenstein's Garden City: with sewage spilling into the rivers, Oswald Pohl needed to give in somewhere--especially as he lacked the resources to install a system capable of dealing with the waste that the camp produced. When the sewage came up as the last point of the agenda, Pohl chose to humbug his way through the issue. The municipal and provincial bureaucrats, who had just won an important victory concerning the relocation of the SS settlement, allowed him to get away with it. All agreed that the matter needed the special attention of Himmler, and that they would meet again in the near future to resolve the sewage problem. 65

Thus began a period in which the creation of various provisional and more sophisticated sewage treatment plants became a major obsession in the Auschwitz Zentralbauleitung (Central Construction Office) (fig. 19). Designs became more intricate and technologically advanced, but work on the ground progressed slowly. Only in July 1943 was Bischoff able to complete the first provisional sedimentation basin just south of the recently completed Crematory II (fig. 20). This was to service BA I of Auschwitz-Birkenau, which had already been completed a year earlier. Because it was located adjacent to the crematory at the windward side of the camp, the basin only sharpened the all-pervasive excremental stench of the place. Progress on the provisional treatment facilities of BA II, north of Crematory III, was slow, as there were no guards to oversee the prisoners assigned to dig the channels. 66 When Pohl visited the camp on 17 August 1943 the completion of the sewage plants was the central topic of discussion. Bischoff explained that one of the difficulties in constructing the system was the lack of guards to oversee the prisoners: the treatment facilities had been planned outside the camp's barbed wire fence, and the channels that had to be dug ran for more than three miles through lightly guarded terrain. A massive deployment of prisoners, needed to complete the project that year, would be possible only if the camp could provide a steady and predictable supply of guards. Knowing that Bischoff was hysterical on the issue of prisoner labor, Pohl decided to see the site for himself. 67 He must have urged the camp to heed Bischoff's request, because for several weeks a great deal of work was done. But by mid-September the supply of guards started to dry up, and progress was halted.

Bischoff's inability to complete the sewers because of the lack of guards points to what was perhaps the greatest fallacy of Himmler's original proposal to use slave-labor to build up the German East. Himmler had been inspired by two precedents: the Reichsarbeitsdienst (Reich Labor Service) and the Soviet Gulag. The Reich Labor Service, which had become manda-tory on 26 June 1935, had been established to do exactly the kind of work that Himmler expected from slave labor. By 1937 the programs of the Reichsarbeitsdienst affected one fifth of Germany. 68 The organization was involved in the reclamation of marshes, the draining and irrigation of underdeveloped land, the concentration of fragmented farm properties, the protection of lowlands by dikes, and the reclamation of land from the sea. But the men of the Labor Service worked with minimal supervision. They did not need guards. They took pride in their work. And the hundreds of thousands of prisoners within the Soviet Gulag worked most often in desolate areas in which an escape from the camp meant certain death in the wilderness. Himmler, however, had to deploy his slave labor (fig. 21) in a highly developed environment and, as the war continued, with dwindling manpower to guard them. Birkenau's original purpose had been unattainable from its inception.

This brings us to the camp's transformation from a prisoner-of war-camp into a concen-tration camp for Jews. I will neither analyze nor seek to explain this transformation, but limit myself to recording some facts. From the moment of their arrival the Soviet prisoners of war, who were supposed to build their own accommodations, had died more rapidly than the SS expected. Höss recalled how "the situation became really terrible during the muddy period in the winter of 1941-42. They could bear the cold, but not the dampness and wearing clothes that were always wet. This, together with the primitive, half-finished, hastily thrown-together barracks at the start of Camp Birkenau caused the death rate steadily to climb" (Höss, 133). Snow began to fall at the end of November. Höss sent a report to Berlin indicating a catastrophic situation. In response Kammler phoned Bischoff on 3 December, and demanded a full report within twenty-four hours. Bischoff's statement introduced the bad news with some statistics meant to impress on Kammler the extent of his progress until now: in just over a month 140,000 cu. ft. of earth had been moved, 1,600 concrete foundations had been poured, and 86,000 cu. ft. of brick work had been erected, using 1.1 million bricks. Further, 600 concrete posts had been erected for the fence, and 100,000 stretching ft. of barbed wire had been put into place. The bad news was that only two of the huts in BA I had been completed, twelve had been provisionally enclosed, seven were advanced enough that work could begin on the girders, and nine already had walls under construction. 69 [Begin Page 114]

A major reason for the slow progress was that the Russians had not been supplied with building materials. Bischoff's original brief, drafted in October, had mentioned that "the barracks will be for the greatest part built from brick as there is no wood available and the material will be partly derived from the demolition of the hamlet of Birkenau." 70 Thus the first batch of Soviet prisoners of war were told to cannibalize the village; they had already been brought to the point of cannibalizing each other, as Höss later admitted when recalling this early period in the history of the camp:

Cases of cannibalism happened quite often in Birkenau. Once I found the body of a Russian lying between two piles of bricks. The body had been ripped open with a dull instrument. The liver was missing. They beat each other to death just to get something to eat...During the levelling of the land and the trench-digging in the first section of Birkenau [BA I], the men discovered several corpses of Russians apparently beaten to death and partially eaten...[The Soviets] had become animals who looked for only one thing, food. (Höss, 133f.)

Not only did SS overseers withhold materials from the subhumans, they also furnished no tools to cannibalize the houses in Birkenau. They were to be pulled down with bare hands, and the barracks built likewise. This contributed to the high mortality rate during construction. In the month of October, 1,255 Soviets died; in November, 3,726; in December, 1,912; and in January, 1,017. By the end of January almost 8,000 of the 10,000 men had died, which translates into a mortality rate of 240 percent per year. One more month would suffice to kill the remaining 2,000.

The SS now began to look for a new source of labor. On 26 January 1942 Himmler com-municated his new plans to the inspector of all the concentration camps, Richard Glücks. "As Russian prisoners of war are not expected in the near future," Glücks was to take charge of the "large number of Jews and Jewesses who are being emigrated from Germany, and send them to the camps...During the next few weeks, prepare to receive 100,000 male Jews and up to 50,000 Jewesses in the concentration camps. Large-scale tasks and assignments will come to the concentration camps in the next few weeks." 71 Himmler's communication spelt more doom than might at first appear. The Jews were not to be housed in a concentration camp set up according to Kammler's guidelines, but in Bischoff's infinitely more primitive prisoner-of-war camp in Birkenau. Three years and one day after Himmler's telegram the Soviet Army liberated Auschwitz. Early Soviet estimates put the number of people killed in those three years at close to four million. Today we believe that the number is more like one million.

Appendix

Auschwitz: Explanation of the Master Plan

"Geographical Situation. Auschwitz is located in the midst of a fertile, loessial landscape that stretches between the Beskid Mountains in the south and the Upper Silesian hills in the north. The loessial terrace, which drops almost ten meters where it reaches the flood plain of the Vistula, pushes toward Auschwitz far to the north. At the point where the Vistula regains its eastern direction after having run north for some time, there was once a natural ford just above the meeting place of the [tributary rivers] Sola and Pzemsa with the river Vistula, while the terrace that offered steep slopes on three sides offered a point of departure for the thirteenth-century German foundation of a town in the shadow of a ducal castle.

Natural Traffic Situation. At Auschwitz the roads that come southwest from the Moravian Gate and south from the Beskid Mountains through the Sola valley meet the world trade route that connects the North Sea to the Black Sea.

Location. Today, Auschwitz is also a place where many important roads and railroads meet ...Its location is determined not only by the fact that Auschwitz is a central place in the region, but also by its good traffic location within the larger space. That is to say, Auschwitz occupies more or less the center of the Moravian, the Upper Silesian and the Polish indust-rial areas. Also significant is its location at the immediate periphery of the Upper Silesian coal mining area. The choice of this site as a location for large industries is made feasible by the presence of an almost flat, large, dry loessial terrace of more than two hundred acres that can be developed, and the bountiful supply of water in the Vistula valley.

Population. The present population situation in Auschwitz (Administrative District) is as follows:

Auschwitz-City12,500 (among which 7,000 Jews)
Babitz2,500
Birkenau4,500
Broskowitz400
Dwory2,200
Monowitz1,200
Stare-Stawy750
------
Total around25,000 (The number of ethnic Germans is insignificant.)

Population Planning. Because of the importance of the location, the future population has been set at 35,500 people, in addition to which there will be two reserve areas for 11,500 people, creating a total potential population of:

47,000 inhabitants.

Thereby we assume the following division of the population:

Percentage of people employable (after Rechenberg): 55% of the population. Hence 35,500 x 55% = approximately 19,500 employable people.

Percentage of this number employed to service the town and its region: 45% of the employable people (minimum according to Rechenberg 35%, increased because of the town's position as a central place in an otherwise rural area, with important traffic functions--government, trade, traffic, crafts, small industries. Hence 19,500 x 45% = local significance: 8,800.

Number of workers in the large industries: Buna [the IG Farben plant]--3,000; rolling mill--600; other--400. Total = 4,000.

Railways and ancillary businesses = 1,500.

SS and ancillary businesses (but not the barracks and the concentration camp inmates)

500 settlers x 3 = 1,500.

Reserve and otherwise employed = 3,700

Total employed (8,800 + 4,000 + 1,500 + 1,500 + 3,700) = 19,500

Space Needs of Settlement. In the enlarged municipal area we aim to house all 35,500 inhabitants in the settlement areas described below:

This suggests an average land use of 200 m2 per house, according to the land-use tables developed by Rosenberg; the population density of 115 inhabitants per hectare is, according to my own research, an average for a mixed, generally two-story, open and continuous arrangement with streets in between, lined by three-story buildings.

Planning of Districts. The point of departure for general planning has been the assumption that the only area suitable to large industry is the zone located east of the town--at the town's leeside--south of Dwory. A natural area for human settlement is offered by the nearly flat and dry terrace, which stretches west of the town and immediately adjacent to it. On the basis of considerations for safety from bombardments, the settlement area is separated from the industrial area by a depression of 500m. This area must be developed as a park-like green belt.

This is all the available space than can be used for settlement immediately adjacent to the existing town core.

The existing urban area is constructed around the medieval core, which will be preserved with its Ring. It will serve in first instance as the center of government and commerce.

Further, a natural expansion of the town can occur in the adjacent area between the sta-tion and the Sola. Because relocation of the station is impossible, this area is the only pos-sible...zone for city expansion. This will lead to the creation of an organic connection between the city as a whole and the station, of which the main hall will be pushed 300m east in order to create a new station square with a post office, a hotel and similar amenities. This expansion settlement area, which will be able to house 10,000 people, will also give space for the SS settlement and a settlement for railroad employees, each with 500 houses, with in total 2 x 500 x 4.5 = 4,500 inhabitants. The part of this area that is located north of the through road will be reserved for light industries...

Separated by a green belt from the settlement area adjacent to the station is an area of 35 ha for the SS base, which at its northwest corner touches on the existing mill.

Another green belt separates the SS base from the concentration camp proper, which is approximately 150 ha in size. The agricultural areas that are necessary for the purposes of the camp are defined in such a way that the organic development of the town will not be obstructed and no important road connections will be interrupted. For the rest it is assumed that the rivers Sola and Vistula will be the natural borders [of the concentration camp area].

As small industries can be located in the settlement area at appropriate locations, a further industrial area has not been planned. If necessary at a later date, one might consider creating another industrial area west of the station, stretching west toward the Vistula. The establish-ment of SS industrial installations might begin there, and, because of this possibility, a long-term agricultural development should be avoided in that location.

Traffic Planning. At the railroad an expansion of the station is foreseen...The spine of the traffic within the town will be defined by the narrowly shaped connector that links the station, crosses over the existing Sola bridge, and passes through a cut in the old town to the settlement area of East Auschwitz. Also at the town core will be a new Ring that will be a center for government, party, and community buildings. This area will be connected to the regional road to the north and a small railway station. The industrial road will continue east through a park-like green belt to the place where the main gate and the industrial offices will be located...

Free Areas and Recreation. The valleys of the Sola and the Vistula with their borders shall be kept free. The flood plain south of the town will become dry even during periods of flooding after flood controls around the Sola have been completed, and can hence be used for sports facilities and small gardens. A cemetery that can be expanded, with an immediate surface of 35,500 inhabitants x 3m2 = 10 ha, is also foreseen. Because of the new bridge over the Vistula the forest at Bobrek and Chelm can be easily reached.

Water and Sewage Treatment. An area in the Sola valley has been designated as a water control zone...An area has been allocated for sewage treatment, but we must still decide on measures to protect it from floods." 72

Robert-Jan van Pelt is Associate Professor of Architecture at the University of Waterloo, Canada. He is the author of Tempel van de Wereld: De Kosmische Symboliek van de Tempel van Salono , De Binnenhof , and, with Carroll William Westfall, of Architectural Principles in the Age of Humanism . The essay published here will form part of a new book, The Origins of Auschwitz, to be published in spring 1995 by Yale University Press.

1.1 1-3

Editorial/Introduction

Lawrence Rainey and Robert von Hallberg

We begin this journal in the belief that the artistic movement known as modernism produced the most radical and comprehensive changes in western culture since romanticism. Here would be the place to list those changes, if only they were all nameable and known, like characters in a chapter of yesterday's reading. Instead we sense that the effects of modernism still reverberate through all the arts, and its products surround us in the buildings where we work, the houses and apartments where we live, and even the chairs where we sit now trying to itemize its effects. Modernism was more than a repertory of artistic styles, more too than an intellectual movement or set of ideas; it initiated an ongoing transformation in the entire set of relations governing the production, transmission, and reception of the arts. The modernists themselves seem to have understood this when they urged that changes in the arts be viewed in conjunction with changes in philosophy, historiography, and social theory, to say nothing of the scientific shifts that they claimed as part of their moment's cultural revolution. The success of modernism was so great that we all feel ourselves to be latecomers: postmodernism is the term now invoked to assert an epochal shift away from our parents' perspective.

We hope that every issue of will convey some sense of the grand ambition and scope of artists and intel-lectuals of the first half of this century. This is to say that this journal will look widely at the art and thought of this period, but also that we want to examine the sense of contestation that was essential to it: between old and new orders, of course, but also among various divi-sions of the intellectual endeavor. We hope for a journal that not only records and explains some of the crossings between architecture and political thought, say, or between music and economics; we want the essays and reviews we publish to attempt similar crossings. We will be pleased to publish essays and reviews by sociologists on literary history, for example. We won't always be able to find this sort of work, but we will always be looking for it, and will regularly ask our authors to push toward their neighboring disciplines in the hope that readers will recognize the appropriateness of this ambition in a journal devoted to the study of modernism, even when they may disapprove of poachers on their own particular territory.

The particular examples of border crossing that we've cited will suggest one of the two major ambitions of the journal. One is simply to maintain a sense of the international dimensions of modernism. An essay about a New Jersey poet, as is evident in this first issue, may sit next to another about German expansion into Poland. Our other, more difficult objective is to bring into dialogue writers in the social sciences engaged by issues of modernity and modernization and scholars of the literary and fine arts committed to the history of modernism in the arts. Scholars of the humanities have borrowed a great deal lately from social, political, and economic historians, and procedures of literary inter-pretation have influenced the writing of history as well; but we have a long way to go before we can claim that these two large divisions of professional intellectual activity are in dialogue with one another. In the pages to follow we intend to experiment with various ways of encouraging collaboration, though we know that it will be much easier to retain the international scope of modernism than it will be to facilitate exchange across the disciplinary boundaries separating literary critics and political theorists, economists and musicologists.

For the first few issues of we have chosen themes that will allow us to draw into the journal writers from various scholarly disciplines. Our first theme is modernism and race, a subject crucial both to modernism and to the social transformations of modernity. For while the modernists frequently advocated internationalism in art and politics, they also drew on folk or ethnic traditions that seemed to preserve intact vestiges of sensibilities not yet tainted by the processes of modernization, doing so in a period that also experienced intense nationalism in Europe and the mounting force of interethnic encounters mediated through travel, immigration, colonialism, and early anthropology. We have had no difficulty finding fascinating work on this topic--indeed we have given over our first two issues to it. Although we have seen many studies of aspects of this subject in the past few years, we want to hold this focus long enough to suggest how the history of modernism might look if we took race as an originating concern of modernism, as some of the authors included in this issue argue that we should. Future issues will take up such themes as anarchism, religion and secularity, fascism and culture, and the institutions of art, and we will devote some issues to single res or movements such as F.T. Marinetti and the Futurists, Wyndham Lewis, and Igor Stravinsky.

Although our editorial policies are not intended to encourage methodological conformity of any sort, the essays that appear in this first issue will rightly suggest that the journal will be primarily concerned with historical understanding, though that is an umbrella to cover a crowd. We do hope to attract writers of various methodological and political commitments to contribute to this collaborative effort, and we want as well to include the work of writers, musicians, and artists as well as professional scholars. We will try to attract to these pages work by established and well-known scholars as well as by young and lesser-known writers. What we will ask of all our authors is a commitment to clear expression with a minimum of specialized terminology; a plain style, we think, is necessary to an interdisciplinary effort like the one we've described.

Those are our hopes and desires, but the product of our efforts will doubtless turn out to be quite different from what we expect. This is after all a collaborative effort with colleagues from whom we have not yet heard. We hope for a conversation whose outcome is hard to foresee.

We have received encouragement and moral support from many colleagues at Yale and Chicago, and elsewhere too. Here we want to record our gratitude to Charles H. Long, Deputy Provost at Yale, and Philip Gossett, Dean of the Humanities Division at Chicago, without whose material support we could not have started this project. Now we look forward to the support of our subscribers to keep us going.

.

1.1 4-16

The Turn-of-the-Century Concept of Race

George W. Stocking, Jr. *

At a meeting of the American Antiquarian Society in 1895, after hearing a paper on "The Scotch-Irish in America," G. Stanley Hall, president of Clark University and one of the country's leading psychologists, remarked that he did not know of "a better illustration of the beneficial effects of crossing different stocks than this." Hall was not generally in favor of race mixture, but he was willing to make an exception in this case, because the brain fibers of the Scotch and Irish fitted so neatly into each other's cranial interstices.

The Irish race anthropologically regarded is, as a stock, remarkable for its vitality, for its esprit, for its ready wit, for its quick susceptibility to all relations with all things and all men around it. On the other hand, the Scotch mature later, and from the stand-point of brain analysis they must be as remarkable for the fibers that connect the parts of the cortex one with the other, the so called 'association fibers,' as the Irish brain must be for the 'projective fibers' connecting with the external world. [The product of their] "favorable commingling of bloods is seen in the Scotch-Irish race;...they are not only more susceptible to all environments outside, but their activity is prolonged to a greater period of age.

Hall made it clear that much more was involved in the "commingling of bloods" than simply physical characteristics. "The combination of racial bloods is not a mere matter of biology or physiology...because physical inheritance does not include mere physical mingling of the bloods, but [also] that subtle atmosphere of associations, of home traditions, of family recol-lections and ideals and aims, that are so inseparable."

From the American Antiquarian Society meetings in Boston to the chambers of the United States Senate is a step out into the wider American society of the 1890s. But where the speaker is Henry Cabot Lodge, the transition is an easy one, and indeed the pattern of assumption is not dissimilar. Speaking in favor of immigration restriction in 1896, Lodge argued that though a Hindoo might "absorb the learning of Oxford" and even sit in Parliament, he could not be made an Englishman, even though they both came from the "great Indo-European family." It had taken "six thousand years and more to create the differences which exist between them," and these could not be effaced by education in a single lifetime. Lodge went on to ask what was the "matter of race which separates the Englishman from the Hindoo and the American from the Indian?"

It is something deeper and more fundamental than anything which concerns the intellect. We all know it instinctively, although it is so impalpable we can scarcely define it, and yet it is so deeply marked that even the physiological differences between the Negro, the Mongol, and the Caucasian are not more persistent or more obvious. When we speak of a race, then,...we mean the moral and intellectual characters, which in their association make the soul of a race, and which represent the product of all its past, the inheritance of all its ancestors, and the motives of all its conduct. The men of each race possess an indestructible stock of ideas, traditions, sentiments, modes of thought, an unconscious inheritance from their ancestors, upon which argument has no effect. What makes a race are their mental and, above all, their moral char-acteristics, the slow growth and accumulation of centuries of toil and conflict.

To move from scholar to scholar-politician to fictional Irish saloon-keeper is hardly to encompass all levels of late nineteenth-century American society, but for present purposes we will go no further than to note that similar assumptions seem to underlie the thinking of Mr. Dooley. Mr. Dooley felt that the trouble with the Cubans was that they didn't "undherstand our civilization." To us, freedom meant hard work; to the Cuban, it meant blissful idleness. "Ye can't make people here undherstand that, an' ye can't make a Cubian undherstand that freedom means th' same thing as a pinitinchry sintince.... Th' Cubians ain't civilized in our way. I sometimes think I've got a touch iv Cubian blood in me own veins."

In 1896, the processes and the problems of heredity were little understood, and "blood" was for many a solvent in which all problems were dissolved and all processes commingled.
