Then, onward. As I was walking among the raging fitful gleams of the floodlights on the Austrian shore I heard weeping alongside me, just above me, within me. The beautiful body was weeping, and the tears were dripping onto my back, burning slowly slowly.

Passages 7-8. On 22 March 1918 Marinetti was assigned just north of Thiene (a small city about one hundred and sixty kilometers north of Vicenza). Passage 7 shows him, a day after his arrival, testing and refining sentences around one of his favorite themes, the sun as a symbol of the power of destruction and renewal of the Futurist hero, as seen in the third chapter of Mafarka le futuriste, "The dogs of the sun," where the sun both decomposes the cadavers of the dead and ploughs the fields to nourish the warriors. 24 as Marinetti writes in The Steel Alcove, "The sun of lava communicates with my heart through invisible tubes, communicating vessels." 25
Passage 8 comprises two parts. The first consists of two sentences written toward the work that would eventually become 8 Souls Within a Bomb , a sequence of eight stories that "explodes" at the end. More interesting is the abrupt shift to the second part, Marinetti's recollection of an event that had taken place almost exactly three years earlier, on 11 April 1915, when Marinetti and Mussolini were both arrested in Rome. The occasion was a demonstration on behalf of interventionism, one of a series staged in the principal cities of central and northern Italy on the same day. They were organized by the "Fasces of Revolutionary Action," a leftist group that strongly favored intervention and many of whose documents and theoretical writings were printed by Mussolini in Il Popolo d'Italia.Mussolini was speaking as a representative of this group when he was arrested in the early afternoon and was released in the evening on the condition that he leave Rome immediately. 26

[7.] 23 March 1918

Boastful sun.
The sun's boasting at twilight.
The last boasting of the sun, says the disdainful moonlight.
An assault of pressing smells.
The pressing light.
The sun is palming off its false coins.
The thick river sated with corpses is undulating toward the sun like a serpent that has just eaten.
Demagogue sun.
Tribunal sun.
The sun has taken off its shirt and is yelling over the elegant hilltops.
Aristocratic sun.
Dictator sun.
The deserter sun is crawling into the underbrush.
The motion picture sun projected its film of gold, vibrant and dusty.
The thick intrigues of the black waters; the sea overcome by shadows.

[8.] 5 April 1918

For Five Souls Within a Bomb.

One sleeps really deeply after having punched some low and traitorous scum in the snout.

Fifth Soul:

Everyone makes fun of me because my name is goooood-willl! I like dogs and sweet creatures and little affectionate women.

Mussolini in the middle of about a hundred republicans and revolutionaries. I in the middle of about fifty Futurists. An exchange of glances, fraternal and full of solidarity.

Be begins to speak. The sound of water crashing in the Fountain of Trevi. Two wagons ready.

Settimelli and Bruno Corra are near me. I Scream: "Down with Austria!"

Suddenly twenty hands of policemen. Bruno and Settimelli are defending me with blows and trying to prevent the arrest. But my whole body is lifted up and placed inside a wagon and away we go amid a cyclone of blows and punches. On the way an officer tells me that Mussolini is in the other wagon behind mine, also having been arrested.

Passages 9-12. In early July 1918 Marinetti was assigned to the Corps of Armored Cars. After receiving his initial training in Genoa he was ordered to join the Eighth Armored Squadron stationed between Venice and Padua, where he remained for three months (25 July to 24 October). We give four passages from this extraordinarily productive period just prior to the end of the war.
Passages 9 and 10 are a sketch for an episode in the work that came to be called Futurist Loves , though ultimately it was not included in the finished volume. Marinetti first mentions the larger project in a diary entry for 18 March 1918: "I am thinking about the Futurist Loves. Programs for life, with ramifications. Which is to say, with variant endings. Two or three or four possible endings, each different from one another, which a reader can then choose." 27 The
passages' central image, connecting melancholy, pessimism and "D'Annunzian poisons" to an infection of the sexual organs, is recurrent in Marinetti, and appears, for example, in A Woman's Belly: A Surgical Novel (1919; see note to passages 21-23 for more details). Ettore Petrolini and Leopoldo Fregoli, both mentioned in the sketch, were variety performers who were able to respond to the rapid improvisational rhythms of Futurist theater and early comic film. 28
Passage 11 presents an extensive narration of the battle of Caporetto, which had taken place a year earlier, as experienced by one Captain Raby, who served with Marinetti in the Corps of Armored Cars and who res prominently as a fictional character in Marinetti's work The Steel Alcove , a novel closely based on Marinetti's experiences in the war's final year. To what extent Marinetti altered Raby's account cannot be determined, but it differs greatly from his own experiences as recorded in the diaries. More important, Raby's account sounds many of the notes that were heard in public debate about the disaster, the scope of which had left Italy profoundly shocked. After the breakthrough on 24
October 1917, the Italians were forced to retreat more than two hundred kilometers in eighteen days, battered by incessant rains and constant shelling. When
it was over they had suffered 40,000 casualties (dead and wounded) and lost 280,000 prisoners and 350,000 more who were separated from their units or had deserted. Less than half of the army was left at full strength. Explaining "the disaster" became a national obsession and the account of Captain Raby is partly a contribution to that debate, as well as a distillation of Marinetti's own wartime experiences. Only a portion of the narration is presented here, enough to indicate Marinetti's understanding of the disaster's "real cause" and his flair for condensed narrative.
Passage 12, in contract, looks forward to the end of the war, already immanent, and attempts to assess its "lessons" for the postwar period to follow, touching a subject also addressed in the satire The Island of Kisses in which two of daring Futurists unmask a band of homosexual museum lovers who want to prevent technological progress and war.

[9.] 1 August 1918

Joy or Sorrow at Will.
(One of the Futurist Loves.)
A Program of Life (or of pleasure) with variants to one's own liking.

First you have to become an assistant to Bossi. Then go into the provinces: Pisa, Pistoia, Gubbio, Perugia, cities either dead or half-dead, and flush out a young lady who is very pale, nostalgic, sick with sentimental indecision, and fond of passeist literature. Respectfully ask for her hand. Then make her fall in love with you by using all the old and decadent epistolary poisons of the D'Annunzian sort. When she's yours, blurt out monstrous revelations about your infidelity as a man of orgiastic temperament. Her spirit is shattered. Her fragile body grows ill. Neurasthenia. Longing for suicide. Persuade her parents, then personally take your betrothed into the clinic of Professor Bossi in Genoa right on the sea, so clear and rich in cubic afternoons of flowing gold and torrid sunlight.

In the extremely white operating room (odor of chloroform), she is lying down, extremely white, on a white bed.

You must speak to her of the necessity of forgetting you and of falling in love with a weak young pallid sick neutralist who has been discharged after a case of enterocolitis and a liver illness, yet is respectful, Platonic, and full of elegant sorrows.

You will see, rising from the lower stomach of your betrothed, a greenish phosphorescence that little by little will become a lunar ray. (Outside, a cloudy night as dark as pitch, sultry warmth as heavy as pitch.) The ray strikes the jalousie of the window. A hole is opened by the oxhydrogen blowpipe. Outside the ray is now thrusting forward and inundating the night and the sea with a marvelous and mournful moonlight.

A dialogue, under the lunar trees, between your beloved and the ideal.

"To be yours. Yesss. But that can never happen! Never! Our lips will never meet!"

"I understand your soul! I cannot reach the terrible limit of truth. You will never know the secret of my renunciation."

Doctor Bossi enters. Together with him, you will examine the vagina of your beloved.

"Damn that phosphorescent light. A basket of putrefied fish must have been left here!"

[10.] 7 August 1918

Continuation of Joy or Sorrow at Will (futurist loves)

They look beneath the bed.

"There's no basket of fish down here!"

"Well then, it's quite simple! It's a case of shrivelled uterus with pockets of menstrual puss! You know what the operation consists of."

Then, Bossi having departed, you will speak to your beloved of the necessity of becoming a singer of light music, meanwhile pressing the wound in the uterus with a light massage. You will repair the ege of the uterus. You will wash it and take away all the pus.

Then you will go out into the garden and lie down on the grass about 100 meters from the window of the operating room. After 10 minutes an extraordinarily white ray will leap out from the pierced jalousie and fill the nocturnal garden which, bathed in bright light, will reveal red armchairs that teem with naked shoulders and pearls, that bristle with astoundingly luminous osprey feathers and dark glances, black diamonds, a frenzied river of jewels.

Rising, you will turn around and see, within the radiant circle formed by the electric floodlights, a stage that is shining, with the actor Petrolini in the middle, agile, jumping about in a black tuxedo worn with a starched shirt-front as white as snow beneath the enemy floodlights....With his mouth, with his eyes, Petrolini is imitating grimaces, guffaws, hunger, thirst, ironies, thanks, and the prayers of the female vulva.

The actor Fregoli (standing near Petrolini), meanwhile, will imitate all the faces of the mothers, the fathers, the young couples who are there, faces marked by horror, desire, reproach, and exaltation at the sight of the immaculate daughter displaying herself in that way in public. At last, what she had kept hidden beneath her dress is revealed.

The stage has great buzzing wheels, 20 motors each of 200 horsepower. It runs, leaps over plains, climbs mountains, jumps into a river (it looks like a dalabieh or riverboat on the Nile being pulled by unnumerable vieux marcheurs viveurs in tuxedos who are bent beneath the tow-line...on both shores they are pulling the stage as it sputututters and bebebelches its speedy motors over the water like propellers) with ropes like electric rays.

Away! The stage contains your beloved who does a mean cakewalk and then begins a marvellous belly-dance just where the uterus is becoming a spiral a vortex of light warmth perfumes. The stage, like an assault car, launches an attack upon a convent full of elderly respectable English ladies, located on a mountain in Scotland. They are reading the Bible. You take the Bible, mount the stage, and explain how Noah, at the age of eighty, screwed his virgin daughters.

[11. August 1918]

The Retreat of Lieutenant Raby's Five Armored Cars

I was at Maiano with five armored cars. The others were at Turin, in the security service, at Turin with the Captain.

The Night of 25-26 October 1917

They are taking away the telephone from the office (three soldiers from the Engineering Corps placed at my orders) that linked me to the 16th Division. I can hear shelling in the direction of Gorizia. At two o'clock I go to the 16th Division Command at Purgessimo. I pass by Premariacco, transport cars blocking the road. In the place where the cars are parked I learn the tragic news of our collapse and retreat at Caporetto. Two grenades explode nearby. Smoke is billowing over Cividale, fires. They tell me that the first Austrian patrols are already in Cividale. I search for the 16th Division at Remanzacco. They don't know anything there. I eat and go on to Udine. The clearing out of our troops has begun in a tumult of bad news.

I go on to Trigesimo.

"Where is the 16th Division?"

"What army are you with?"

"The Third."

"This is the Second. We don't know a damned thing."

27 October 1917

At Trigesimo I finally find the 16th Division. The second in command says to me: "What are you doing here?"

"I'm looking for a place to hide the general's car!! I don't have time to waste with you!"

At last I find General Ponzio, who says to me: "Bravo! If only all the officers were like you! Very well. I've lost all my machine guns. I'm going to need you."

Ponzio describes the conration of our troops in retreat. Gorizia (the Army's "Zone of Gorizia"). Lucinico, Rubrio, Trigesimo, Artegna, Gemona--all of Carnia has already been lost. "We're meeting tomorrow at Casacco. But remember to pass below Udine, because the road from Trigesimo to Udine is being shelled." The defense was to be on the river Torre.

The night of the 28th I pass by Udine. It is pouring rain. Disorder, panic. The wounded and the ill cleared out in haste. Stretchers everywhere, wounded. Screams of terror. Cars, ambulances, the drone of airplanes as they surge upwards in the dark. Fields with oxen. Cattle, cows, carts. Cannons overturned. Fires, fires. The vast blushes of red in the night against the maniacal tenacious filaments of rain turning into tears over the countryside stricken with terror. Casacco. Artegna.

I am fired on by rifles that are shooting from Monte Stella. Then I run into twelve Alpines. "We're all that's left of a battalion! The Austrians are up on Monte Stella!" And then I run into a major coming with two guns from the mountains. "I'm retreating. Ammunition is finished. I've been shooting until now."

I go on, passing by the fiery blast, the enormous hot burning breath of the old spinning mill at Artegna, in flames.

At Buia. Avella. Maiano. Deveacco. Farla.

The Morning of the 29th

The 16th Division has been merged with the 34th Division to form a unit named the "Di Giorgio Special Corps," which has been assigned the task of holding the bridgehead at Pinzano, with regrouping on the river Ledra.

I originally had five armored cars, but from Udine to Buia I've lost three. With two cars and some outposts of the Cavalry (Umberto Regiment) I am to cross back and forth from Buia to Avella and Avella to Buia. Exchanges of fire with Austrian patrols. Pouring rain.

The Night of the 29th

San Tommaso, Command of the 16th Division. They receive a communication from the Command of the Syracuse Brigade reporting that Maiano has already been occupied. Maiano is two kilometers away from San Tommaso. Panic in the Command. A retreat is discussed.

"If you want," Raby says to the general, "I'll go and see."

Rain. Darkness. Carts abandoned on the roads. I go around via the country roads. Empty houses. I think that I'm in a village near Maiano. I run into a peasant.

"What village is this?"

"Maiano."

I examine some houses. I go to the intersection of the roads going to Peri and Tonzolano. Nobody. Rifle fire in the distance. I return to San Tommaso to make my report.

Dawn of 30 October

The 16th Division is folding back to the river Ledra. I am to stay behind with two armored cars and a battalion of Alpines.

At Buia we see six Austrian cavalrymen outlined against the sky in the hills. I fire with my machine gun. They disappear. They were three hundred meters away.

The bridges over the river Ledra are being mined.

At midday I return to our lines. I am in the divisional reserves.

At twilight, an attack by the Austrians, who are coming from Udine. There is a persistent rumor (started by the Austrians): the Third Army has already reached Trieste and has taken 60,000 prisoners!!! Soldiers keep on passing by and shouting: "This is the road to Trieste!" Then they throw down their weapons!

11:00 on 30 October

I take an armored car and go to Maiano. I'm accompanied by a battalion of the 246th Infantry. Their captain is energetic, powerful, bold. Maiano has been occupied by the Austrians. They have six machine guns. Three are standing pointed in a row in the middle of the road, left visible, stupidly. I'm told that during the night one of our battalions had occupied Maiano, but that it was chased out in the morning by the Austrians. Now they are holding the city with six machine guns transported with bicycles.

With my machine gun, at a distance of 50 meters, I take aim at the three machine guns in the open road. I am standing at a corner. One blast and the Austrian machine gun in the middle is overturned. I see the gunner, who had been lying behind it, with his stomach to the ground, rising and attempting to get up. His chest and stomach have an enormous hole torn out, 30 centimeters in diameter, from which blood is flowing in streams in rivers to left to right inundating the street which is already filled with water and turning it all red. The three machine guns have been smashed and overturned. The other gunners are fleeing into the nearby houses, among the bicycles that they had placed under the porticos. The dead gunner, who had gotten bloodily entangled in the tripod of his gun, is crushed by the armored car as I pass over his body. I take away the other two guns in the armored car; they're about a yard high. My tires are shredded. There is the smell of gunfire. Pursuit into the houses. My sergeant, the driver, chases one Austrian gunner and stabs him against the shut door of a house.

The other three machine guns that were targeting us, hidden in a stack of corn on the right, have grown silent. The captain of the infantry battalion has been struck in the chest and falls dead. The battalion is falling apart as it retreats. I fall back. My two Maxims have been disabled. The radiator of the armored car is leaking, riddled by bullets. I return to San Tommaso.

The 16th Division has already left. They are firing at me from the church, situated in a high part of the town. I send the other armored car to sector 193 just outside the town in order to fire from the same height as the church. Grenades, the 75ers, are falling around us rrrrrrrr but land without exploding. I reach the other car commanded by Lieutenant Failli. My two cars fall back from Farla to San Daniele. Patrols. Rifle fire.

I know that San Tommaso has been occupied by the Austrians. I run into a captain from the 1st battalion of the Eighth Fortress, who has lost all his weapons and is leading his men disarmed. At Villa Farlate there are some blasts from machine guns which disabled the last two of Failli's guns that were still firing.

At San Daniele del Friuli, a town that sits upon a hillside, I find myself at the bottom of the city in a road that twists upward with s-curves. At the top of the town are our two machine gun companies. I clear the street of overturned carts, then go up on foot. I receive orders from the Rovigo Brigade to disable the motors of my armored cars and to take the remaining machine guns that work and resist as long as possible. At whatever cost. The command of the brigade sends me two boxes of cartridges.

In the passageway of a country house I find a cart, on which I screw down the machine that loads the cartridge belts. Helped by an old refugee woman, I load the belts with my men. Meanwhile, my drivers are weeping as they break up their motors. I prepare some cartridges with gunpowder for mines in order to blow up the gasoline tanks.

[12. 18 October 1918]

Theories of Spring

The spring with its tearing and overflowing rivers of war-revolution for the new ideal flowers that are seeking the sky.

Codification of Spring. The Laws of Spring.

Revision of all laws. Why have they been condemned? One has to weigh modify or destroy the checks prohibitions imposed by society (living together order security = cowardice) on the free rapacious incestuous assassin spring.

1. Should humanity once again become incestuous? No! not even for the sake of experience.

2. Should humanity once again become a predatory robber? Yes! for the sake of experience. The recent conflagration has proved it.

3. Should humanity have a vast experience of promiscuity and sexual intercourse? Yes! The recent conflagration has quite abundantly shown that.

4. Should humanity be bloodthirsty? Yes! The conflagration has demonstrated that.

5. Should humanity be homosexual? No! The conflagration having demonstrated the necessity of an abundant destruction of life, everything that is contrary to the reproduction of the species must be combatted. But homosexuality can be a useful experience in order to devaluate woman (lasciviousness, sentimentalism, fidelity).

Passage 13. Marinetti's meeting with Benedetta Cappa, an aspiring writer and gifted painter, was undoubtedly the most important event of his personal life during the period 1917-21. His earliest dated letter to her is from 15 June [1918], but it was plainly preceded by several others. 29 Nine years later they married and eventually they had three daughters. The passages given below are found among loose leaves that follow a diary entry dated 3 November 1918, but their date is hardly secure. "Marinetto" is a pet name that was used by "Beny," as Benedetta came to be called.

[13. Late 1918]

Dreams of Beny

First, music of Edgar Poe, all in violent snatches, executed by three trams on the taut musical strings of the tracks of the piano-city. And from the tumultuous tangle of the feverish and tragic notes it forms and releases an ideal re.

[Late 1918]

1. It is Marinetto's duty to think about Beny every morning and every evening.

2. It must be his pleasure to serve her every day.

3. He must desire to see her as soon as possible.

4. He must dream of kissing her.

5. He must be joyful only in love, in loving Beny ever increasingly.

Beny adores Marinetto with all her soul. So it is.

Passage 14. The Dolina of the Carso or The Nightingale of the Plava was a work that Marinetti planned, but never completed. It was to thematize the lessons of the war in the re of a nightingale whose song was transformed to harmonize with the sound of factories and cannons. Toward this work, then, Marinetti plans to draw on his own experience when he was wounded on 14 May 1917 at Plava (see the note to passage 5). The Café Savini, in Milan, was frequented by writers in Milan in the years before the war.
The haunting image of Marinetti "accartocciato nel camminamento" (crumpled like paper in the communication trench) recalls the poet Giuseppe Ungaretti's description of himself in "Dolina notturna" (nocturnal doline), a poem dated "Naples, 26 December 1916," which first appeared in 1918: 30 "Questo nomade / adunco / si lascia / come una foglia / accartocciata // L'interminabile / tempo / mi adopera / come un fruscio" (this nomad is left like a crumpled leaf, time consumes me like a rustle; lines 6-16).
The "dolina" was, in Marinetti's own words, "a depression in the terrain of the Carso. It looks like the crater of a dead volcano. Sometimes a real circus dug out by the waters. A little dried-out lake." 31 It was typically used as a shelter by the soldiers--including Marinetti and Ungaretti--in Worlld War One.

[14. Late 1918]

For the Dolina of the Carso or in the Nightingale of the Plava, render the hunger that I felt at Plava when wounded on the stretcher next to the dissevered leg of an Alpine, while a former waiter of the Savini Café in Milan (where I had lived through so much) offers me his sympathy and some exquisite broth, etc. I eat it, thinking about the mysterious roads of the Forces and coincidences. Also render my worry at the Parello dolina upon hearing it declared that the three infantrymen who had died in the communication trench had been crumpled like paper by death. I thought that if I had died as they did, they would have written fairly if they had defined me as one who was: crumpled like paper in the communication trench.

Passages 15-17. The year 1919 signalled the moment of Marinetti's most intense political engagement. On 11 January he joined Mussolini in leading a group that disrupted a speech at La Scala by Leonida Bissolati, the head of the reformist Socialists and an advocate of moderation on the question of how much territory Italy was to receive after the war. On 23 March Marinetti joined Mussolini in forming the Fasci italiani di combattimento (Italian Battle Fasces), the organization that became the Fascist National Party. By the end of the year he was under arrest and imprisoned for twenty-one days on charges of keeping weapons and engaging in subversive activities. The three passages given here range widely in nature and tone. Passage 15 is a sketch for brief play of the "synthetic theater" sort. Passage 16 probably dates from late September or early October 1919, and apparently recalls a moment during Marinetti's visit to Fiume (15 September to 2 October), where he had gone only three days after D'Annunzio's take over of the city. It is both harsher and more honestly admiring of D'Annunzio than any of his published remarks, which are instead marvels of satirical ambiguity, beginning with his short "biography" The Gods Depart, D'Annunzio remains . 32
Passages 17, in contrast, suggests Marinetti's deepening interest in questions of practical morality, questions that he explores by assimilating Nietzschean thematics of the strong or forceful individual to a vein of scientific mysticism turning around the concept of "forces" at work in the universe. In his notes for the novel based on his later war experiences, The Steel Alcove , he repeatedly pondered giving it the subtitle: The Book of Forces; and in chapter three of the novel, "The chemical battle and the azure halos," he describes the "halos of lived life," in which are gathered "all the affective forces of couples, friends, parents, children, mothers, lovers and little children that, united with the forces of past pain and pleasure, shield the soldiers." 33

Entries from 1919

[15. Between 25 March and 5 April 1919]

Percussion Suicide.

A young woman abandoned by her lover opens the window and desperately calls to him. The lover, already in the street, looks up and sees the girl sobbing and screaming. She leaps over the windowsill. He opens his arms and receives her falling body on his chest. He falls beneath her weight and breaks a leg! They are married, naturally, cemented together by that dynamic suicide.

[16. Late 1919]

[Previous page missing] the worst [impression] that D'Annunzio left on me, smiling with the grimace of a cretinous whore at the salutations of the soldiers: "All of them were recognizing me and saluting me!" A strange mixture of heroism and genius and petty pederastic vanities in this superior man, strong tenacious patriot, mystically disinterested and also so vain that he would perhaps ruin Italy for the pride of being or seeming to be the head of the revolution. Yesterday he was, at bottom, a sort of traditional reactionary; today he is undisciplined and ready for any form of violence. He wants to lead everybody and everything. He is greatly deluding himself.

I think that I am better than him: disinterested, more secure, and indifferent about possible successes and ambi[tion...next page missing].

[17. December 1919]

The Knowledge of Forces

1.) Mix great boldness with detailed prudence. Alternate a grandiose blind thrust with a religious concern for being prudent about particulars.

2.) The use of amulets should sometimes be a form of homage or a genuflection to Forces that have been angered or gone mad.

3.) There are shifty or halfway sorts of beings who are of no interest to the Forces. They live in the shadow of what surrounds them; they are never caught in the cyclonic movement of the Forces. Others, instead, are always at the center of the breach or in the middle of the road. These must always choose the type of movement in which it is possible for them to turn the current that is taking them along in order to redirect it then with the impetus added by the enthusiasm of the Forces themselves. Otherwise they must give themselves over to the current, changing themselves from opaque rafts to giant floating luminous things, so that the Forces themselves go more quickly toward a new harmony.

4.) Magicians say: You want to have something? Say in a loud voice: I possess it. A loud voice, naturally. This is true for halfway people who neither have nor can have much influence.

5.) A magician said that I was a crowd. I tell Beny that she's a crowd of beauties.

6.) To say some things out loud is very dangerous. For the Forces can overhear a voice and sometimes reject it absolutely. To repeat out loud certain ideas reinforces them, makes them real.

7.) Humans are open like porticos or rooftops or blocks of flats without windows and doors. They can be invaded by another soul or by many other souls. Others are closed and can't be invaded. Still others are extremely open, but their inner personality is so compact active and powerful that souls that penetrate it cannot resist that internal dynamism and end up leaving immediately.

Passages 18-20. Unlike the violent waves that attack the stars in The Conquest of the Stars, the crepuscular and languid waves described in passage 19 recall the seductions of Coloubbi at the end of Mafarka the Futurist, and the hypnotic music of the "Lake of Poetry and Sentiment" where the Untamed are purified of their violence. 34

Entries from 1920

[18. Circa 31 March 1920]

The will anatomically transforms the body. It increases the capacity of the stomach, which can contain such a quantity of liquids. The will can forbid the body from transmitting inebriation from alcohol to the brain. I have never been drunk except when I softened my will. I have maintained my will like a guardian of order until I wanted it otherwise. Then I softened it. And in turn this softened the body. Sudden dizziness and absolute vomiting.

[19. August-September 1920]

The Seductiveness of Evening by the Sea (A free-word assessment.)

The optical nerves are relaxing. Coolness spreading over the cheeks. A summation of all the olfactory acoustical caresses soothings mildnesses silkinesses shadings. The slowness of the tepid breeze that is becoming cooler. Soft mother-of-pearl shades, lilac pink green turquoise, torpid rhythms of the sea's movements, delicate childish swinging of diminutive waves; the gentle wry face of the shimmers all the shimmers pink lilac purple blues greens of the sea; they are straining to melt into the half-effaced shades of sky (to form an immense shell of bluelilac coolness). The lighter boats are straining to keep their balance, as if not to burden the waves. The oars dip delicately, not wanting to tear the sea-silk. They rise gracefully, not wanting to ruffle the edges of the wave's little scars. Undulating agile metallicity of the waters that will resolutely resonate and sing of sweetness. The soft velvety look of the navy slacks and crimson cap in the white boat. Each boat is a set of scales that is weighing the woman at the prow against the man at the stern.

Boats: fruitdishes that offer women cadenced by the blue music of the cool waves pallid with pleasure. In the bluecool high sea, look, the dark oars of the boat which rhythmically dip and rise with delicacy and precision, as if not to wrinkle the rare silk of the sea.

Ssssssssss gggggg The wave is sweetening its murmurs, its languors, perfecting itself before becoming a sound that is drunk by the ear ecstatic like an aroused eye, mouth, heart.

The beach is falling asleep, extinguishing the flashing footlights of its theatrical stage, closing its sandy eyelids beneath the fringes of white slow spume faint ever fainter more sluggish.

The Splendor and Folly of Midday by the Sea. (A free-word assessment.)

The massive scenic stage of the high sea at calm, a dance of wave-ballerinas, silvery frenetic butterflies. Typographic boat of gaudy placards, with the little rotary press of the rower moving like a piston and printing printing endlessly printing flowers of vermilion and gold on the rolls of blue paper furnished by the sea.

[20. August-September 1920]

Against memory. Nostalgia as negation of new and joyous effort. Nostalgia.

Against the historical document. Patience, a restraint that exasperates good fortune and makes it flee.

Futurism is the formula for optimistic mental hygiene; a projection, passionate and fraught with faith, of the I in action; a conquest and shaping of tomorrow.

Passages 21-23. The first two passages are difficult to date because they are fictional, and on loose sheets of paper inserted into the diaries pertaining to 1921. Passage 22 outlines a method for overcoming the oscillations of fortune through an "artificial optimism opposed to all chronic pessimism, a continuous dynamism, a continuous becoming and an indefatigable will." 35 It is later developed into the "futurist cure," entitled "courage + truth," that Marinetti develops in his fictional letters to Enif Robert 36 (mentioned in passage 22) who must undergo an operation and recover from severe depression in the novel they co-wrote in 1919, A Woman's Belly: A Surgical novel . 37

[22. Date unclear]

[Page missing.]

2. An attempt at a Futurist cure.

My letter to Signora Enif Robert and her reply.

3. Never speak of Impossibility.

Declare that everything that is desired and everything that is wanted is possible. Never say, "I am unlucky. I'll never be able to do it"

4. Keep silence in matters that are relatively easy and prepare them carefully. You should want them fiercely, but not say to others that you'll succeed. Never say it's a sure thing, even when a favorable outcome seems certain. To say it's certain is the same as considering oneself the master of auspicious forces. But the forces like to consider themselves free not to favor someone even when they have already made their decision. They are kind, but surly and easily irritated with people who are strong. It is necessary to say we hope or perhaps! For if they hear you say, it's a sure thing or I'm certain, they can abandon you brutally without reason.

5. Creative force of the word.

A terrible passion a terrible and pernicious love can be created in us just by the force of saying, "I'm in love" or "I'm smitten with that woman. I can't live witout her." Example: Carmissati. His lover, already fucked by others as well as himself might have remained his model and his lover. But he felt himself to be Tristan and saw in her his Isotta, and by means of the music of Wagner at La Scala he artificially created his drama of love. The piercing separation. Her brother understood the situation and took her away from him, encouraging the musical tragedy with its crescendi of violins--anxiety--blood sperm that rises falls rises rises toward the spasm of the full orchestral conclusion. There's no one but her. To marry her! Mine! Mine!

But she was already his! Marriage was necessary only to render more Wagnerianly romantic a love that was already naturally romantic because free. Literary superimposition. To perfect a love with weak artifice by means of the instinctive physiological element of music.

You can create a political state of mind in favor of war or revolution with a simple cry: Down with Austria or Death to Giolitti. We have to take Mount Cucco. "I've got Mount Cucco in my pocket," as Cappello said at the dawn of the action of May 1917. The more difficult a collective revolution is to achieve, the more one must repeat, insistently and with iron crystalline adamantine faith, the will to realize it. It is necessary not to say, the war with Austria is a sure thing. One must say down with Austria! with faith and adamantine optimism. One must say I want I have to have that woman. Don't say: I'll have her for sure. The cry down with Austria, shouted with force and with faith precisely when out intervention was and seemed to be the least likely event, was an adamantine drill in the glass bell of the Germanophile clerical moderate conservative quietist neutralism. It was a force of a quality absolutely opposed to the other one, and therefore it pierced it.

6. The electric light has killed the sunset (indecision nostalgia shadings of pessimism); agony of the solar force that man tends to imitate; the pain of the sun that must yield to the shadows. We no longer see the fields that grow pale and die under the rattlings of churchbells. Electric light extends the full natural day with a full artificial day.

7. Speed has killed eliminated the visual analysis of the countryside and the psychological analysis of the antimuscular internal life. Speed has created the synthesis of a life deliberately thrown up in great blocks and withdrawn from minute pessimism. Pessimism is minutiae, detail, analysis. Optimism is synthesis. For that reason speed is optimism because velocity gathers together and synthesizes life. Velocity kills memory, folding back upon oneself, remorse. Velocity attacks, it does not suffer; it is almost always the master of life and its forces. Slowness is subject to others and is always a slave of life and its forces.

8. Destroy the frills of one's own life. Simplify each thing in order to be able to dominate a greater number of affairs. One must have a hundred things simplified and coarsened in one's own life. One must never have anything tied up or made ornate with a thousand useless frills.

Destroy all tricks masks cosmetics ribbons of important things. Reduce every important matter to its state of raw nudity. That way you can dominate many important matters and make a complex synthesis of them directed toward its perfection and splendor. Frills prevent us from seeing the direction of their strength. Important things, once stripped liberated from their frills, can reveal their power and their direction to us. Thus one can identify the one two or three directions of the twenty or thirty things-forces that are really important, and so life converges towards its true ends.

9. Establish a bridge with artificial optimism (constructed of whatever elements are at hand, even fragile and worn out ones) between one good occurrence and another, striding over the valley of the bad event. This is based on the already universally acknowledged law of the oscillation of fortune and misfortune. After the good the bad, after the favorable the unfavorable. Rollercoaster of events. Create a bridge from the good to the good and over the bad.

10. Artificially keep up the situation at all costs when there is support on the right and the left and when the circumstances dictate that the perilous situation, viewed within the context of all the other situations, may turn out favorable. The Countess D'Orsay leaves tips of 500 liras "in order to preserve her station," as the Countess Robilant of Florence says. She's right. The act of the Countess partakes of artificial optimism and is quite right and useful for the entire environment that wants the Countess D'Orsay to rise and not sink. The tips prevent her from having to fall to the point of accepting some miserable little job, which would not be honorable because it would mark a fall and would depress a person ill-suited to such work.

11. We must cultivate, educate in ourselves, our vanity, rendering it, however, charming and not aggressive. Thus one should give oneself numerous tasks and numerous peaks to conquer. For the zig-zags of fortune and misfortune will so turn out that a piece of good luck in politics will be matched by bad luck in love or vice versa. And therefore one is never overcome by any single misfortune. We should never renounce our possibilities. We should remove all the frills from our objectives, but have many of them.

12. Once you have decided on a given offensive in life, employ your own forces to the utmost and use a violent attack without indecision, not worrying about possible losses or the labor involved. After you have taken all the necessary precautions, attack resolutely and desperately.

13. When life seems to offer truces; when one is at the crossroads, in a swamp, in the bogs, at a stopping point where the dimness of indecision slowly falls like night; when the situation becomes serious, ambiguous, full of checks and prohibitions masks and half-way measures; when everything around us seems to say, if only this or that were not in my way, or if only I weren't afraid of revealing everything to the husband by some action taken against my flirtatious or unfaithful lover, I would slap her, I would punch her other lover; when every kind of logic seems to dictate immobility--then, instead, one must smash every obstacle with sudden violence and decisive attack. (Rimini, Gabriella, etc. The public gardens of Milan.) For the forces of the universe are like men: they fall asleep when they think they are secure. Thus the unfavorable forces fall asleep when it seems absurd that you should attack them. Precisely for this reason you must choose the moment of maximum confusion tumult indecisive swamp in order to attack them and sink them.

At Plava every logic counseled us not to take the Cucco head on. Indecision, mistrust, too much time passed beneath the Austrians, pressing upon their heels. Not only the Austrians but the superphysical forces of the Cucco were shattered and in disorder when Cappello decided, precisely then, to launch the great frontal assault against the mountain that had always been deemed impregnable and especially so after sitting there for some two years.

When you find yourself in this state with a woman whom you want to seduce; when you find yourself in a long pause after fruitless attacks of no importance; when you feel skepticism, or think that it's useless to attack and certainly right now it's absurd to do so--this, instead, is precisely the moment. But with violence and fierce decisiveness. Right to the very end.

14. Always be close to strong men. They give you voluntarily, or they always let you take, a part of their useful forces. They enrich all who approach them. If those who are strong should take some of your strength (which rarely happens), it's not bad, for they won't lose that force, but use it, and your force, having been utilized by them, will create others that will be at your service. There is, therefore, always profit for you in living close to strong people.

The weak, those who are depressing, besides depressing disheartening discouraging and rendering your forces anemic, suck off your forces sometimes with the intention of utilizing them, but they aren't able to do so and they waste them, leaving them in agony. This gives the contagion of destruction to your other forces. Sometimes they suck off your forces with the deceitful intention of not using them and just losing them. Betrayal discourages and devalues your good forces. What they take away from you is irremediably lost and harmful. Weak and depressing people (such as Ada Negri) say: Don't make me laugh, because I don't want to have to cry someday when remembering these happy hours!!!

15. Always use the antidote of happiness against all sufferings and against all misfortunes. When you lose someone dear to you and are assailed with terrible suffering, use the surefire antidote of revivifying obscenity.

The mother of my friend Enif, a strong and energetic woman, tall, powerful, sixty years old, of distinguished personality and will, loves the lottery games to the point that she will almost ruin herself with a big weekly game. Yet she never opens the envelopes that the office of the lottery system sends her. Even though she's a subscriber! I think that she does it to maintain, within herself, that hope-almost-certainty of winning from one moment to the next. In effect she is a subscriber to the pleasure of being able to get the winning combination of numbers. This is artificial optimism. She doesn't open the envelopes because what matters to her most is this continual probability of winning, which gives her a continuous optimism, and because when she actually opens the envelopes she experiences a series of sorrows in finding out that she hasn't won. This woman of superior instinct lives quite intelligently in her isolated villa at Spazzavento, content and calm, without melancholy, with her nerves in good health. She is also given over to social pleasures, which is to say to the better life that she leads by means of her telephone, which gives her the certainty of communicating with everybody. So she lives in almost absolute solitude, but with a sense of society and a wider life concentrated in the telephone that communicates with Florence, Milan, etc. The enormous importance that the telephone has in her dining room in the solitary villa. She once told me that in her worst moments of sorrow she was fond of composing obscene popular songs. This is strange, given that she never speaks obscenities herself and is not given over to salacious tales. It is the antidote of sorrow. The best antidote, because obscenity is happy and funny, energetically chasing and burning away sorrow and disgrace, which are always full of chastity and the austerity of physical renunciation.

16. Always take the initiative in everything. In America there are schools of initiative. Every day and several times a day a prize is given with little sums of money to the student who knows his lesson. There are no punishments, but one is rewarded with money. The hours outside of class and the vacations are used by the students in earning as much money as they can, in all honest ways and with every possible effort. Thus, in the twelve-year-old student, for example, are awakened the desire and the skill for living on one's own according to one's own instinct, intuition, judgment. An admirable way to develop the spirit of business and commercial initiative in a young boy.

17. Take into account the forces of Fortune and the forces of Misfortune, which is to say all the favorable and all the unfavorable forces that are not yet well known, but exist. Napoleon believed that his generals would prove able in times of war to the degree that they proved intelligent in times of peace, and more or less unfortunate or fortunate. Their good luck or bad luck was the more important point of view for judging them.

18. The art of scenting, deciphering, and utilizing forces.

19. Learn everything in life by living it, not watching it.

[23. 10 November 1921]

Facist Procession after the Convention

Three-thirty in the afternoon. A leaden sky. Frozen wind. Solemn march of 40,000 fascists from the Piazza del Popolo to the Altar of the Patria, the Monument to Vittorio Emmanuele. Hundreds of black red pennants. The black in the pennants and in the silk shirts of the fascists predominates. They carry the pennants in front like compresses. In the wind the billows of the crowded black red flags are seething. Dynamic seething of Balla. At the head of the procession, after a small band, Mussolini in a large and wide rust-colored coat, carrying a walking stick and balancing it. His step is measured. This huge crude proletarian with his Caesarean head, his heart swollen with the savor of revenge on his former socialist companions. After crossing in front of the monument, he extends his arm in salute to the Unknown Soldier. The band:

tiraram tirarim
tiraram ram
tiraram tirarim
tiraram ram

[1.] 31 Marzo 1917

Sempre sempre, nella mia vita si alternarono questi due stati d'animo tortus torturanti: Nel letto più voluttuoso e felice mi sono ad un tratto strappato alle braccia d'una amante deliziosa e buona, e seduto fremente ho teso l'orecchio ad un lontano immaginario bombardamento. Nostalgia desiderio d'eroismo e di violenza. Nella trincea fango broda delle bombarde mostruosa edera rampicante di corpi nudi di donne dalle mie tempie fino alla luna. Nostalgia torrida di lussuria. Perché? Perché? 38

La Reine Bordel

Questa cameretta di legno tutta scossa dalle cannonate + rumore che fa il mio soldato cuoco nel grattare il formaggio simile a quello che faceva la mia vecchia Angiolina a Godiasco (15 anni fà) + una fila di bambine quindicenni guidate dalla bruna ia di Stanny a Amsterdam, tutte trattenendo le risatine furbissime passano e danno una carezzetta un lieve buffetto al membro ritto mio. Io sono coricato e fingo di dormire nella mia camera aperta sul giardino lun lunare. Primo giro: buffetto. Dormo sulla schiena nudo. 2š giro più audace: Nous allons lui mettre un abatjour sur le visage pour qu'il ne se reveille pas!

Passano e una dopo l'altra alzano una gamba prendendomi la faccia tra le cosce. Io lecco furiosamente. Ognuna vibra dal piacere dieen dichiarando con tono serio: Oh! il ne se reveillera pas. Tandis que l'une se f Mentre l'una si fa leccare l'altra mette un identico abatjour sulla candela del mio membro e se lo se lo stro frega contro la fica. La bruna ia di Stanny mi sussurra passando che vuole farselo entrare nel culo e che io goda così. Il gioco finisce così. (La Reine Bordel)

[5.] 27 Settembre 1917

Immagino una fucileria di trincee da una parte all'altra del lago nelle piante lacustri (che emergono e sono talvolta tutte sommerse quando il lago cresce molto) sotto il discorso della luna.

Discorso della luna ai Combattenti (per il romanzo)

Mi sdraio tra di voi, dure trincee e vi spalmo lentamente colla mia dolce bava saliva di lumaca e l'olio della mia saliva argentea. Lasciatevi intenerire dure irte scabre sornione trincee! Perché vi battete? Perché vi contendete questo stagno inutile assurdo al quale non potrete nemmeno dissetarvi. L'acqua è troppe avvelenata di luna. Io sola regno qui. Questo lago non è né Austriaco né italiano. È mio. È un lago della Luna! Via addormentatevi e deponete il fucile e dormite.

--Taci, gridò una sentinella italiana, o luna tu sei Austriaca. Taci o ti centro col mio fucile!

--No no gli mormorò un altra sentinella italiana. La luna è italiana. Non la senti eantare una eanzone di Napoli canta come si canta al mio paese! La luna è italiana Questa luna è italiana.

È per questo che io la butterò giù con un colpo di fucile. Lascia fare a me. Sono tiratore scelto futurista! E fu così che La luna tramontò sul lago di Doberdò al crepitare d'una fucileria della fucileria.

Diventa assistente di Bossi. Poi va in provincia Pisa Pistoia Gubbio Perugia città morte o semimorte e snida una signorina pallidissima nostalgica malata d'indecisione sentimentale e di letteratura passatista. Domanda rispettosamente la Sua mano. Poi innamorala con tutti i vecchi veleni epistolari decadenti D'Annunziani. Quando è presa precipita su lei delle rivelazioni mostruose su la tua infedeltà di uomo orgiastico. La sua anima si sfascia. Il corpo fragile si ammala. Nevrastenia Suicidomania. Persuadi i parenti e conduci tu stesso la tua fidanzata nella clinica del prof. Bossi a Genova in riva al mare chiaro ricco di meriggi cubici d'oro rovente e di sole torrido.

Nella sala delle operazioni bianchissima (odore di cloroformio) è coricata bianca nel letto bianco.

Tu parla della necessità per lei di dimenticarti e di amare un giovane pallido neutralista malato senza forza eso riformato per enterocolite e malattia di fegato, ma rispettoso platonico pieno di tristezze eleganti.

Dal basso ventre della tua fidanzata vedrai sorger una fosforescenza verdastra che poco a poco diventerà un raggio lunare. (Fuori notte nuvolosa pesante di pece, caldaia marina di pece.) Il raggio colpisce la gelosia della finestra. Buco aperto da quello [?] cannello ossidrico. Fuori si slancia il raggio e allaga la notte e il mare d'un meraviglioso chiaro di luna tristissimo.

Dialogo sotto gl'alberi lunari della tua fidanzata e dell'ideale:

-- Essere tua Siii Ma questo non può avvenire! Mai! Mai le nostre labbra si uniranno!

-- Comprendo la tua anima! Pero Non posso giungere all'orlo terribile della verità. Non saprai mai il segreto della mia rinuncia.

Entra il Dottor Bossi. Tu esaminerai con lui la vagina della tua fidanzata:

-- Accidente a quella luce fosforescente. Qui deve essere rimasto un canestro di pesci putrefatti!

[10.] 7 Agosto 1918

Continuazione di
Gioia o dolore a volantà
(amori futuristi)

Si cerca sotto i letti.

-- Non ci sono canestri di fe pesce qui dentro!

-- Allora è semplicissimo. Si tratta di utero accartocciato con saccoccia carica di pus mestruale! Sapete quale è l'operazione.

Allora (uscito Bossi) tu parlerai alla tua fidanzata della necessità di fare la canzonettista e premerai intanto nella piega del'utero con lieve massaggio. Rimetterai a posto l'orlo. Laverai l'utero e toglierai tutto il pus.

Poi andrai fuori in giardino e ti coricherai nell'erba a 100 metri dalla finestra della sala di operazioni. Dopo 10 minuti ecco un raggio bianchissimo elettrico sfreccerà dalla gelosia forata e riempirà il giardino notturno che illuminatissimo rivelerà tutte le sue poltrone rosse piene di spalle nude con perle e irte di asprì vertiginosamente luminosi e di occhiate nere diamanti neri frenesia di fiumi di gioielli.

Ti volterai alzandoti e vedrai nel cerchio radioso dell del riflettore elettrico il palcoscenico splendere con in mezzo Petrolini agile saltellante in frack nero sparato bianchissimo (di neve alpina sotto i riflettori nemici...). Colla bocca cogli occhi Petrolini imita le smorfie le risate la fame la sete le ironie le grazie e le preghiere della vulva femminile.

Fregoli intanto (vicino a Petrolini) imiterà tutte le facce delle mamme dei padri dei fidanzati intorno, di orrore di desiderio di rimprovero di esaltazione al vedere la ia immacolata così manifestarsi pubblicamente colla faccia illeg alfin rivelata che teneva celata sotto le gonne.

Il palcoscenico ha le ruote dietro romban[ti] 20 motori di 200 cavalli l'uno. Corre si slancia traversa le pianure sale le montagne beccheggia in un fiume (sembra una dalabieh sul Nilo trascinata da innumerevoli vieux marcheurs viveurs frack (curvi sotto la gomena, [?] sulle due rive tirano il palcoscenico che fa sbrrruffare rrruttare i suoi motori veloci sull'acqua come eliche) con corde di raggi elettrici.

Via via via. Il palcoscenico colla tua fidanzata che danza il cake wake benissimo poi comincia una meravigliosa danza del ventre dove l'utero diventa spirale vortice di luce calore profumi. Il palcoscenico (come un carro d'assalto) dà l'assalto a un convento pieno di vecchie dame inglesi su una montagna della Scozia. Leggono la Bibbia tu prendi la bibbia monti sul palcoscenico e spieghi come Noè [?] infilzò 80enne le sue vergini ie.

[11. ottobre 1918]

La Ritirata delle 5 blindate del tenente Raby

Ero a Maiano con 5 blindate. Le altre erano a Torino servizio di publica sicurezza a Torino col Capitano.

(25-26 notte Ottobre 1917)

mi portano via il Telefono dall'ufficio (3 soldati del genio a mia disposizione) che mi collegava alla 16 divisione.

Sento che bombardano verso Gorizia. Ore 2 vado Comando 16 Divisione Purgessimo. Passo da Premariacco. Ingombro carreggi. Al parco automobilistico conosco la notizia tragica della ritirata e sfondamento a Caporetto. Cadono 2 granatoni. Fumate su Cividale incendi. Mi dicono che a Cividale ci sono le prime pattuglie austriache. Cerco la 16 Divisione a Remanzacco. Non sanno nulla. Mangio e vado a Udine. Comincia lo sgombero in una ridda di notizie gravissime.

Vado a Trigesimo:
-- Dove è la 16a Divisione?
-- Lei di che armata è
-- della 3a
-- Questa è la 2a non sappiamo nulla!

(27 Ottobre 1917)

Trovo a Trigesimo la 16a. Il sotto capo stato maggiore mi dice:
-- cosa viene a fare qui?
-- Sto cercando il posto per la vettura del generale! Non ho tempo da perdere!

Trovo il generale Ponzio mi dice:
-- Bravo! Se tutti gli ufficiali fossero come lei! Bene! Ho perso tutte le mie mitragliatrici. ho bisogno di lei!

Ponzio mi descrive lo schieramento delle nostre truppe in ritirata Gorizia (armata Zona di Gorizia). Lucinico. Rubrio. Trigesimo. Artegno. Gemona. La Carnia è tutta già perduta!

-- Si trovi domani a Casacco. Si ricordi però di passare sotto Udine poichè la strada Trigesimo-Udine è cannoneggiata. La difesa era sul Torre.

Passo per Udine la notte del 28. Piove dirottamente. Disordine panico. Feriti e malati sgombrati in furia. Barelle. Feriti. Grida di terrore. Carri. Ambulanze. Ronzare di aeroplani che spiccano il volo nel buio. Parchi di buoi. Buoi vacche carri. Cannoni rovesciati. Incendi. Incendii. Rossori vasti nella notte su le reti impazzite accanite della pioggia che si rovescia in lagrime sulla campagna col terrore. {xxx} Casacco. Artegna.

Sono accolto da fucilate che vengono dal monte Stella. Incontro 12 alpini:
-- Siamo--dicono--i superstiti d'un battaglione! Gli austriaci sono sul monte Stella!
Incontro un maggiore con 2 pezzi da montagna:
-- mi ritiro. Finite le munizioni Ho sparato fino ad ora.

Passo nella vampa e nell'alito infuocato enorme bruciante della Filanda di Artegna in fiamme (notte del 29)(all'alba del 29) a Buia. Avilla. Maiano. Deveacco. Farla.

(nella mattina del 29)

La 16 Divisione colla 34 Divisione forma il corpo speciale Di Giorgio che deve form tenere la testa di ponte di Pinzano con schieramento nel fiume Ledra.

Avevo 5 macchine ma da Udine a Buia per ho perduto 3 macchine. Sono con 2 macchine e avanposti di Cavalleria (Regg. Umberto) a fare una crociera da Buia a Avilla e da Avilla a Buia. Fucilate colle pattuglie austriache. Piove dirottamente.

(Notte del 29 Ottobre)

San Tommaso. Comando 16 Divisione. Ricevono un ordine dal Comando di Brigata Siracusa che dice Maiano già occupato dagl'Austriaci. Maiano è a 2 chilometri da S. Tommaso Panico al Comando. Si pensa a ritirarsi.

-- Se vuole--dice Raby al generale--vado a vedere.

Piove. Buio. Carri abbandonati sulla strada. Faccio un giro per strade di campagna. Case vuote. Credo essere in un paese vicino a Maiano. Trovo un contadino:
-- Che paese è questo?
-- Maiano.

Visito le case. Vado agli sbocchi delle strade di Peri e di Tonzolano. nessuno. Fucilate lontane. Torno a S. Tommaso per riferire.

(Alba del 30 Ottobre)

La 16a Divisione si ripiega sul Ledra. Rimango indietro con 2 macchine e 1 battaglione alpini.

A Buia sulle colline 6 cavalieri austriaci contro il cielo sagome nere. Una mia raffica di mitragliatrice. Scompaiono. Erano a 300 metri.

Si Sta minando i ponti sul Ledra.

A mezzagiorno rientro nelle nostre linee.

Sono di riserva di divisione.

Al Crepuscolo un attacco di austriaci che vengono da Udine.

Una voce insistente (d'origine austriaca): La 3a Armata è già a Trieste e ha fatto 60.000 prigionieri!!! Passano soldati che dicono:
-- Questa è la via di Trieste!
e buttano via il fucile!

(Ore 11 del 30 Ottobre)

con macchina vado a Maiano. Sono accompagnato da un battaglione del 246 fanteria. Capitano energico potente audace. Maiano occupato da Austriaci. 6 mitragliatrici 3 sulla strada in riga puntate stupidamente scoperte. Vengo a sapere che nella notte un nostro battaglione occupò Maiano ma fu cacciato all'alba dagl'austriaci. Ora tengono Maiano con 6 mitragliatrici su biciclette.

Colla mia mitragliatrice di culo a 50 metri di distanza io punto le 3 mitragliatrici allo scoperto sulla strada. Sono a uno svolto. Un raffica è la mitragliatric e austriaca al centro è rovesciata. Vedo sollevarsi il mitragliere che era coricato dietro pancia a terra e tentare di alzarsi. Ha nel petto e nel ventre un buco enorme squarciato di 30 centimetri di diametro che schizza sangue a fiotti a rivoli a destra a sinistra inondando la strada piena d'acqua che si arrossa tutta. Le tre mitragliatrici sono spaccate rovesciate gli altri mitraglieri fuggono nelle case vicino fra le biciclette che avevano messe sotto i portici. Il mitragliere morto impigliato sanguinosamente nel suo trepiede è schiacciato dalla mia blindata che passa sopra. Porto via nella mia blindata 2 trepiedi. Sono alti un palmo fissi. Il mitragliere tira pancia a terra. Ho le gomme sfasciate. Fragore di fucileria. Inseguimento nelle case. Il mio sergente automobilista insegue un mitragliere austriaco e lo pugnala contro la porta chiusa d'una casa.

Le altre 3 mitragliere che ci bersagliavano nascoste nel granoturco sulla destra tacciono. Il capitano del battaglione di fanteria è colpito al petto e cade morto. Il battaglione si sgretola ritirandosi. Ripiego. Ho 2 delle mie Maxim fuori uso. Il manicotto bucato dalle pallottole fa acqua. Torno a S. Tommaso.

La 16 Divisione è già parita. Mi tirano addosso dalla chiesa che si trova in posizione alta. Mando l'altra mia macchina sulla quota 193 fuori del paese per tirare all'altezza della chiesa. Cadono intorno delle granate da 75 srrrrrrrrr e s'interrano senza esplodere.

Raggiungo l'altra macchina comandata dal Tenente Failli.

Le due mie macchine ripiegano da Farla a S. Daniele. Pattuglie. Fucilate. So che S. Tommaso è occupato dagli austriaci. Incontro un capitano della 1a batt. del 8 Fortezza che ha perduto i pezzi e riconduce uomini disarmati. a Villa Farlate. delle scariche di mitragliatrici mi mettono fuori uso le mie 2 ancora {xxx} sparanti di Failli.

A S. Daniele del Friuli che è scaglionata su uno collina. Io mi trovo al basso nella strada che sale serpeggiando. In alto del paese nelle case vi sono le nostre compagnie mitragliatrici. Sgombro la strada dai carri rovesciati poi vado su a piedi. Ricevo ordini dalla Brigata Rovigo di inutilizzare i motori e di resistere colle mitragliatrici ancora in buono stato. Ad ogni costo. Il comando di brigata mi manda 2 casse di cartucce.

Nell'androne d'una casa di campagna io trovo un carro. Avvito sul carro la macchinetta per caricare i nastri e aiutato da una vecchia profuga carico i nastri coi miei uomini. Intanto a mazzati i miei automobilisti piangenti spaccano i motori. Prepara le cartucce di polvere da mina per potere incendiare i serbatoi di benzina.

[12. 18 Ottobre 1918]

Le Teorie della Primavera

La Primavera coi suoi fiumi squarcianti e travolgenti

di guerra-rivoluzione per i nuovi fiori ideali che cercano il cielo.

-- La codificazione della Primavera

-- Le Leggi della Primavera

Rivisione di tutte le leggi. Perché sono state condannate? Bisogna dosare modificare o distruggere i freni divieti imposti dalla società (convivenza ordine sicurezza = vigliaccheria) alla Primavera libera rapace assassina incestuosa.

1 L'umanità deve ridiventare incestuosa? no! neanche come esperienza.

2 L'umanità deve ridiventare ladra rapinatrice?

si! come esperienza la conflagrazione l'ha dimostrato.

3 L'umanità deve fare una esperienza vasta di promiscuità e mescolanza sessuale? Si! La conflagrazione l'ha dimostrato abondantemente.

4 L'umanità deve essere sanguinaria? Si! La conflagrazione lo ha dimostrato.

5) L'umanità deve essere omosessuale? No! La conflagrazione avendo dimostrato la necessità di distruzione abbondante di vite umane, tutto ciò che contraria la riproduzione della specie deve essere combattuto. Per svalutare la donna (lussuria sentimentalismo fedeltà) può essere una utile esperienza l'omosessualità.

[fine 1918]

1 È dovere di Marinetto pensare ogni mattina e ogni sera a Beny.

2° Deve essere suo piacere servirla ogni giorno.

3° Deve desiderare di vederla al più presto.

4° Deve sognare di abbracciarla.

5° Deve avere solo gioia nell'amore amare Beny sempre di più.

Beny adora Marinetto con tutta la sua anima. così sia.

[14. fine 1918]

Nel Dolina del Carso o nel Usignolo di Plava dare la mia fame a Plava (in barella ferito) accanto alla gamba d'un Alpino, mentre un ex cameriere del Savini (dove avevo vissuto tanto) mi offre la sua simpatia brodo squisit ecc. Mangio pensando alle strade misteriose delle Forze e delle coincidenze. Dare inoltre la mia preoccupazione alla dolina Parello una mattina nel dichiararmi che i tre fanti morti nel camminamento erano stati accartocciati dalla morte. Io pensavo che morto se fossi morto come loro avrebbero scritto bene se mi avessero definito accartocciato nel camminamento.

Dal 1919

[15. fra il 25 Marzo e il 5 Aprile 1919]

Suicidio a percussione

Una ragazza abbandonata dal suo amante apre la finestra e lo chiama disperatamente. L'amante già in strada alza la testa e vede che la ragazza singhiozzando e gridando scavalca il davanzale, apre le braccia e riceve il corpo piombante della suicida sul petto. Cade sotto di lei e si rompe una gamba! Si sposarono naturalmente cementati da quel suicidio dinamico.

[16. fine 1919]

< >pessima che mi ha fatto D'Annunzio che sorrideva con smorfie da puttana cretina dei saluti dei soldati: "Tutti mi riconoscevano e mi salutavano!" Strana miscela di eroismo e di genialità e di meschine vanità pederastiche in questo uomo superiore forte tenace patriota misticamente disinteressato e anche vanitoso fino a rovinare forse l'Italia per l'orgoglio di essere o parere il capo della rivoluzione. Era ieri in fondo una specie di reazionario tradizionale, oggi è indisciplinato e pronto a tutte le violenze. Vuole capeggiare tutto e tutti. S'illude molto.

Mi sento migliore di lui, disinteressato più sicuro e disinvolto tra i successi possibili e le ambi < >

[17. Dicembre 1919]

Conoscenza delle Forze

1°) Dosare delle grandi audacie con delle minuziose prudenze. Alternare lo slancio grandioso cieco colla cura religiosa delle prudenze particolari.

2°) L'uso degli amuleti deve essere talvolta un omaggio o una genuflessione alle Forze irritate o impazzite.

3°) Vi sono esseri mezzo calibro mezza tinta che non interessano le forze. Vivono nell'ombra dei contorni non sono mai presi nel movimento ciclonico delle Forze. Altri invece sono sempre nel centro del varco o della strada. Questi devono sapere scegliere o il movimento tipico in cui è loro possibile di deviare la corrente che li porta per poi dirigerla col peso accresciuto dall'entusiasmo delle Forze stesse. Altrimenti devono abbandonarsi alla corrente, trasformandosi da zattere opache in galleggianti luminosi perché le Froze stesse vadano più rapidamente verso una nuova armonia.

4°) I maghi dicono: Volete avere una cosa? Dite ad alta voce: la posseggo. A voce alta, naturalmente. Questo è vero per gli esseri mezza tinta che non hanno ne possono avere grande influenza.

5°) Un mago disse che io sono a crowd una folla. Dico a Beny che è una crowd of beauties.

6°) Dire ad alta voce certe cose è molto grave. Poichè le Forze ascoltano la voce e la rigettano talvolta assolutamente. Ripetere ad alta voce certe cose idee le rinforza e le concretizza.

7°) Gli esseri sono {xxx} aperti come portici o tettoie o casamenti senza finestre e senza porte. Questi sono invadibili da una altra anima o da molte altre anime. Altri sono chiusi e non sono da invadere. Altri sono apertissimi ma la personalità interna è talmente massiccia attiva e potente, che le anime che la penetrano non possono resistere al dinamissimo interno e finiscono per uscirne subito < >

Dal 1920

[18. circa 31 Marzo 1920]

La volontà trasforma anatomicamente il corpo aumenta la capacità dello stomaco che può contenere tanto liquido. La volontà vieta al corpo di trasmettere al cervello l'ebrietà dell'alcool. Non mi ubbriaccai che quando mollai la volontà. Io tenni la volontà come un custode dell'ordine finchè volli. Poi mollai la volontà. Questa mollò il corpo. Subito capogiro e vomito assoluto.

[19. Agosto-Settembre 1920]

Il fascino del Crepuscolo sul mare
Il fascino della sera sul mare
(valutazione parolibera)

Si stendono i nervi visivi. Frescura spalmata sulle gote.

Somma di tutte le carezze olfatiche acustiche tattili attenuazioni morbidezze sericità sfumature. Lentezza della brezza tiepida che va rinfrescandosi. Tinte soavi madreperlacee lilla rosa verde turchese ritmo illanguidito delle molle del mare altalene infantili delicatissime delle piccole onde smorfie gentili dei riflessi sforzo espre tutti i riflessi rosa lilla viola azzurri verdi del mare si sforzano di fondersi colle tinte semispente del cielo (per formare una immensa conchiglia di frescura azzurrolilla. Le barche più leggere si sforzano di sollevarsi in equilibrio, per non pesare sulle onde. I remi si tuffano delicatamente per non stracciare la re seta del mare. Si staccano con grazia per non arruffare gli orli delle ferite delle onde. Metallicità ondulata agilissima delle acque che risuoneranno e canteranno certamente di dolcezza. Vellutamento e tarnitura soave d'un pigiama blu e d'una cuffia cremisi in quella barca bianca. Ogni barca è una bilancia che pesa la donna a prua colla misura d'un uomo a poppa.

barche: fruttiere di donne cadenzate dalla musica azzurra delle onde fresche pallide di piacere nel alto mare frescazzurro ecco i remi neri di quella barca si tuffano poi si rialzano di scatto con delicatezza e precisione per non sciupare le belle set sete preziose del mare.

sssssssssss gggggg l'onda addolcisce i suoi rumori languori perfezionandosi prima di diventare un suono bevuto dall'orecchio estatico come un occhio bocca cuore intenerito.

La spiaggia si addormenta, spegne i suoi scintillii lampeggii di ribalta teatrale, chiude le sue palpebre di sabbia sotto le frange di schiuma bianca morbida lenta sempre più morbida lenta.

Lo splendore e la follia del meriggio sul mare

(valutazione parolibera)

Al sommo palcoscenico dell'alto mare calmo una danza di onde ballerine farfalle argentee frenetiche. Barca tipografica

per cartelloni reclame sgargianti, con sopra una piccola rotativa di rematore a stantuffi che stampa stampa stampa senza fine fiori d'oro vermigli e d'oro sui rulli di carta azzurra del mare.
